If N is specified, it becomes the new default for  subsequent[28;15Hd and u commands.[K[29;1H[K[30;1H       J      Like j, but continues to scroll beyond the end of the file.[31;1H[K[32;1H       K or Y Like k, but continues to scroll beyond the beginning of the file.[33;1H[K[34;1H       ESC-) or RIGHTARROW[35;8H       Scroll  horizontally  right N characters, default half the screen width (see the -# option).  If a number N is specified, it[36;15Hbecomes the default for future RIGHTARROW and LEFTARROW commands.  While the text is scrolled, it  acts  as  though  the  -S[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hful is displayed.  Warning: some systems use ^V as a special literalization character.[K[2;1H[K[3;1H       z      Like SPACE, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[4;1H[K[5;1H       ESC-SPACE[6;8H       Like SPACE, but scrolls a full screenful, even if it reaches end-of-file in the process.[7;1H[K[8;1H       ENTER or RETURN or ^N or e or ^E or j or ^J[9;8H       Scroll forward N lines, default 1.  The entire N lines are displayed, even if N is more than the screen size.[10;1H[K[11;1H       d or ^D[12;8H       Scroll forward N lines, default one half of the screen size.  If N is specified, it becomes the new default for subsequent d[13;15Hand u commands.[K[14;1H[K[15;1H       b or ^B or ESC-v[16;8H       Scroll backward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more  than  the  screen  size,  only  the  final[17;15Hscreenful is displayed.[K[18;1H[K[19;1H       w      Like ESC-v, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[20;1H[K[21;1H       y or ^Y or ^P or k or ^K[22;8H       Scroll  backward  N  lines,  default 1.  The entire N lines are displayed, even if N is more than the screen size.  Warning:[23;15Hsome systems use ^Y as a special job control character.[K[24;1H[K[25;1H       u or ^U[26;8H       Scroll backward N lines, default one half of the screen size.  If N is specified, it becomes the new default for  subsequent[27;15Hd and u commands.[K[28;1H[K[29;1H       J      Like j, but continues to scroll beyond the end of the file.[30;1H[K[31;1H       K or Y Like k, but continues to scroll beyond the beginning of the file.[32;1H[K[33;1H       ESC-) or RIGHTARROW[34;8H       Scroll  horizontally  right N characters, default half the screen width (see the -# option).  If a number N is specified, it[35;15Hbecomes the default for future RIGHTARROW and LEFTARROW commands.  While the text is scrolled, it  acts  as  though  the  -S[36;15Hoption (chop lines) were in effect.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[35;1H[35;1H[35;1H[34;1H[34;1H[34;1H[33;1H[33;1H[33;1H[32;1H[32;1H[32;1H[31;1H[31;1H[31;1H[30;1H[30;1H[30;1H[29;1H[29;1H[29;1H[28;1H[28;1H[28;1H[27;1H[27;1H[27;1H[26;1H[26;1H[26;1H[25;1H[25;1H[25;1H[24;1H[24;1H[24;1H[23;1H[23;1H[23;1H[22;1H[22;1H[22;1H[21;1H[21;1H[21;1H[20;1H[20;1H[20;1H[19;1H[19;1H[19;1H[18;1H[18;1H[18;1H[17;1H[17;1H[17;1H[16;1H[16;1H[16;1H[15;1H[15;1H[15;1H[14;1H[14;1H[14;1H[13;1H[13;1H[13;1H[12;1H[12;1H[12;1H[11;1H[11;1H[11;1H[10;1H[10;1H[10;1H[9;1H[9;1H[9;1H[8;1H[8;1H[8;1H[7;1H[7;1H[7;1H[6;1H[6;1H[6;1H[5;1H[5;1H[5;1H[4;1H[4;1H[4;1H[3;1H[3;1H[3;1H[2;1H[2;1H[2;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;15HScroll forward N lines, default one window (see option -z below). Warning: some systems use ^V as a special literalization character.[34;1H[K[35;1H       z      Like SPACE, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[36;1H[K[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[K[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[37;1H[7m-----Info: (*manpages*)less, 1181 lines --Top-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[0m[1;1HLESS(1)                                                   General Commands Manual                                                  LESS(1)[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[2;1H[K[3;1HNAME[4;1H       less - opposite of more[5;1H[K[6;1HSYNOPSIS[K[7;14H?[8;15Hhelp[K[9;13H-V[K[10;8Hless --version[K[11;8Hless [-[+]aABcCdeEfFgGiIJKLmMnNqQrRsSuUVwWX~][K[12;15Hb space] [-h lines] [-j line] [-k keyfile][K[13;15H{oO} logfile] [-p pattern] [-P prompt] [-t tag][14;8H     [-T tagsfile] [-x tab,...] [-y lines] [-[z] lines][K[15;1H            [-# shift] [+[+]cmd] [--] [filename]...[16;1H       (See the OPTIONS section for alternate option syntax with long option names.)[17;1H[K[18;1HDESCRIPTION[K[19;8HLess  is  a  program  similar  to more (1), but it has many more features.  Less does not have to read the entire input file before[20;8Hstarting, so with large input files it starts up faster than text editors like vi (1).  Less uses termcap (or terminfo on some sys‐[21;1H       tems),  so  it  can run on a variety of terminals.  There is even limited support for hardcopy terminals.  (On a hardcopy terminal,[22;8Hlines which should be printed at the top of the screen are prefixed with a caret.)[K[23;1H[K[24;1H       Commands are based on both more and vi.  Commands may be preceded by a decimal number, called N in  the  descriptions  below.   The[25;1H       number is used by some commands, as indicated.[26;1H[K[27;1HCOMMANDS[K[28;1H       In  the  following  descriptions,  ^X  means  control-X.   ESC stands for the ESCAPE key; for example ESC-v means the two character[29;8Hsequence "ESCAPE", then "v".[K[31;8Hh or H Help: display a summary of these commands.  If you forget all the other commands, remember this one.[32;1H[K[33;8HSPACE or ^V or f or ^F[K[34;1H              Scroll forward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more than the screen size, only the final screen‐[35;8H       ful is displayed.  Warning: some systems use ^V as a special literalization character.[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[1;1H[2;1H[2;1H[2;1H[3;1H[3;1H[3;1H[4;1H[4;1H[4;1H[5;1H[5;1H[5;1H[6;1H[6;1H[6;1H[7;1H[7;1H[7;1H[8;1H[8;1H[8;1H[9;1H[9;1H[9;1H[10;1H[10;1H[10;1H[11;1H[11;1H[11;1H[12;1H[12;1H[12;1H[13;1H[13;1H[13;1H[14;1H[14;1H[14;1H[15;1H[15;1H[15;1H[16;1H[16;1H[16;1H[17;1H[17;1H[17;1H[18;1H[18;1H[18;1H[19;1H[19;1H[19;1H[20;1H[20;1H[20;1H[21;1H[21;1H[21;1H[22;1H[22;1H[22;1H[23;1H[23;1H[23;1H[24;1H[24;1H[24;1H[25;1H[25;1H[25;1H[26;1H[26;1H[26;1H[27;1H[27;1H[27;1H[28;1H[28;1H[28;1H[29;1H[29;1H[29;1H[30;1H[30;1H[30;1H[31;1H[31;1H[31;1H[32;1H[32;1H[32;1H[33;1H[33;1H[33;1H[34;1H[34;1H[34;1H[35;1H[35;1H[35;1H[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[37;1H[7m-----Info: (*manpages*)less, 1181 lines -- 0%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[0m[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1HNAME[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       less - If N is specified, it becomes the new default for subsequent d[34;15Hand u commands.[K[35;1H[K[36;1H       b or ^B or ESC-v[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15H# shift] [+[+]cmd] [--] [filename]...[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H(See the OPTIONS section for alternate option syntax with long option names.)[36;1H[36;1H[2;1H[K[3;1HDESCRIPTION[K[4;1H       Less  is  a  program  similar  to more (1), but it has many more features.  Less does not have to read the entire input file before[5;1H       starting, so with large input files it starts up faster than text editors like vi (1).  Less uses termcap (or terminfo on some sys‐[6;8Htems),  so  it  can run on a variety of terminals.  There is even limited support for hardcopy terminals.  (On a hardcopy terminal,[7;8Hlines which should be printed at the top of the screen are prefixed with a caret.)[K[8;1H[K[9;8HCommands are based on both more and vi.  Commands may be preceded by a decimal number, called N in  the  descriptions  below.   The[10;1H       number is used by some commands, as indicated.[11;1H[K[12;1HCOMMANDS[K[13;1H       In  the  following  descriptions,  ^X  means  control-X.   ESC stands for the ESCAPE key; for example ESC-v means the two character[14;1H       sequence "ESCAPE", then "v".[15;1H[K[16;8Hh or H Help: display a summary of these commands.  If you forget all the other commands, remember this one.[18;8HSPACE or ^V or f or ^F[K[19;1H              Scroll forward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more than the screen size, only the final screen‐[20;8H       ful is displayed. If N is specified, it becomes the new default for subsequent d[32;8H       and u commands.[33;1H[K[34;8Hb or ^B or ESC-v[K[35;1H              Scroll backward N lines, default one window (see option -z below). Warning: some systems use ^V as a special literalization character.[34;1H[K[35;8Hz      Like SPACE, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[K[36;1H[K[1;1H[1;1H[K[2;1HNAME[K[3;1H       less - opposite of more[4;1H[K[5;1HSYNOPSIS[K[6;14H?[K[7;14H-help[8;14HV[K[9;13H--version[K[10;8Hless [-[+]aABcCdeEfFgGiIJKLmMnNqQrRsSuUVwWX~][K[11;15Hb space] [-h lines] [-j line] [-k keyfile][K[12;15H{oO} logfile] [-p pattern] [-P prompt] [-t tag][K[13;15HT tagsfile] [-x tab,...] [-y lines] [-[z] lines][14;8H     [-# shift] [+[+]cmd] [--] [filename]...[K[15;1H       (See the OPTIONS section for alternate option syntax with long option names.)[16;1H[K[17;1HDESCRIPTION[K[18;8HLess  is  a  program  similar  to more (1), but it has many more features.  Less does not have to read the entire input file before[19;8Hstarting, so with large input files it starts up faster than text editors like vi (1).  Less uses termcap (or terminfo on some sys‐[20;8Htems),  so  it  can run on a variety of terminals.  There is even limited support for hardcopy terminals.  (On a hardcopy terminal,[21;1H       lines which should be printed at the top of the screen are prefixed with a caret.)[22;1H[K[23;8HCommands are based on both more and vi.  Commands may be preceded by a decimal number, called N in  the  descriptions  below.   The[24;1H       number is used by some commands, as indicated.[25;1H[K[26;1HCOMMANDS[K[27;8HIn  the  following  descriptions,  ^X  means  control-X. If N is specified, it becomes the new default for subsequent d[26;1H              and u commands.[27;1H[K[28;8Hb or ^B or ESC-v[K[29;1H              Scroll backward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more  than  the  screen  size,  only  the  final[30;8H       screenful is displayed.[31;1H[K[32;8Hw      Like ESC-v, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[34;8Hy or ^Y or ^P or k or ^K[35;22H backward  N  lines,  default 1.  The entire N lines are displayed, even if N is more than the screen size.  Warning:[36;16Home systems use ^Y as a special job control character.[36;1H[1;1H[K[2;1H       Commands are based on both more and vi.  Commands may be preceded by a decimal number, called N in  the  descriptions  below.   The[3;8Hnumber is used by some commands, as indicated.[K[4;1H[K[5;1HCOMMANDS[6;1H       In  the  following  descriptions,  ^X  means  control-X.   ESC stands for the ESCAPE key; for example ESC-v means the two character[7;8Hsequence "ESCAPE", then "v".[K[8;1H[K[9;1H       h or H Help: display a summary of these commands.  If you forget all the other commands, remember this one.[10;1H[K[11;1H       SPACE or ^V or f or ^F[12;8H       Scroll forward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more than the screen size, only the final screen‐[13;15Hful is displayed. The entire N lines are displayed, even if N is more than the screen size.[22;1H[K[23;1H       d or ^D[24;8H       Scroll forward N lines, default one half of the screen size.  If N is specified, it becomes the new default for subsequent d[25;15Hand u commands.[K[26;1H[K[27;1H       b or ^B or ESC-v[28;8H       Scroll backward N lines, default one window (see option -z below).  If N is more  than  the  screen  size,  only  the  final[29;15Hscreenful is displayed.[K[30;1H[K[31;1H       w      Like ESC-v, but if N is specified, it becomes the new window size.[32;1H[K[33;1H       y or ^Y or ^P or k or ^K[34;8H       Scroll  backward  N  lines,  default 1.  The entire N lines are displayed, even if N is more than the screen size. Useful if the file is changing while it is being viewed.[28;8HF      Scroll forward, and keep trying to read when the end of file is reached.  Normally this command would be used  when  already[29;15Hat the end of the file.  It is a way to monitor the tail of a file which is growing while it is being viewed.  (The behavior[30;1H              is similar to the "tail -f" command.)[31;1H[K[32;8HESC-F  Like F, but as soon as a line is found which matches the last  search  pattern,  the  terminal  bell  is  rung  and  forward[33;1H              scrolling stops.[34;1H[K[35;8Hg or < or ESC-<[K[36;15HGo to line N in the file, default 1 (beginning of file). Useful if the file is changing while it is being viewed.[26;1H[K[27;1H       F      Scroll forward, and keep trying to read when the end of file is reached.  Normally this command would be used  when  already[28;8H       at the end of the file.  It is a way to monitor the tail of a file which is growing while it is being viewed.  (The behavior[29;15His similar to the "tail -f" command.)[K[30;1H[K[31;1H       ESC-F  Like F, but as soon as a line is found which matches the last  search  pattern,  the  terminal  bell  is  rung  and  forward[32;8H       scrolling stops.[K[33;1H[K[34;1H       g or < or ESC-<[35;8H       Go to line N in the file, default 1 (beginning of file).  (Warning: this may be slow if N is large.)[36;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       J      Like j, but continues to scroll beyond the end of the file.[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       K or Y Like k, but continues to scroll beyond the beginning of the file.[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       ESC-) or RIGHTARROW[36;1H[36;1H[2;1H              Scroll  horizontally  right N characters, default half the screen width (see the -# option). Useful if the file is changing while it is being viewed.[20;1H[K[21;1H       F      Scroll forward, and keep trying to read when the end of file is reached.  Normally this command would be used  when  already[22;8H       at the end of the file.  It is a way to monitor the tail of a file which is growing while it is being viewed.  (The behavior[23;15His similar to the "tail -f" command.)[25;8HESC-F  Like F, but as soon as a line is found which matches the last  search  pattern,  the  terminal  bell  is  rung  and  forward[26;1H              scrolling stops.[27;1H[K[28;8Hg or < or ESC-<[K[29;15HGo to line N in the file, default 1 (beginning of file).  (Warning: this may be slow if N is large.)[31;8HG or > or ESC->[K[32;15HGo  to  line N in the file, default the end of the file.  (Warning: this may be slow if N is large, or if N is not specified[33;1H              and standard input, rather than a file, is being read.)[34;1H[K[35;8HESC-G  Same as G, except if no number N is specified and the input is standard input, goes to the  last  line  which  is  currently[36;1H              buffered.[36;1H[1;8H       Scroll  horizontally  right N characters, default half the screen width (see the -# option). Useful if the file is changing while it is being viewed.[19;1H[K[20;1H       F      Scroll forward, and keep trying to read when the end of file is reached.  Normally this command would be used  when  already[21;8H       at the end of the file.  It is a way to monitor the tail of a file which is growing while it is being viewed.  (The behavior[22;15His similar to the "tail -f" command.)[K[23;1H[K[24;1H       ESC-F  Like F, but as soon as a line is found which matches the last  search  pattern,  the  terminal  bell  is  rung  and  forward[25;8H       scrolling stops.[K[26;1H[K[27;1H       g or < or ESC-<[28;8H       Go to line N in the file, default 1 (beginning of file).  (Warning: this may be slow if N is large.)[29;1H[K[30;1H       G or > or ESC->[31;8H       Go  to  line N in the file, default the end of the file.  (Warning: this may be slow if N is large, or if N is not specified[32;15Hand standard input, rather than a file, is being read.)[K[33;1H[K[34;1H       ESC-G  Same as G, except if no number N is specified and the input is standard input, goes to the  last  line  which  is  currently[35;8H       buffered.[K[36;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hbecomes the default for future RIGHTARROW and LEFTARROW commands. If a number N is specified, it[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hbecomes the default for future RIGHTARROW and LEFTARROW commands.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[2;8HESC-} or ^RIGHTARROW[K[3;15HScroll horizontally right to show the end of the longest displayed line.[5;12H{ or ^LEFTARROW[6;22Hhorizontally left back to the first column.[K[7;1H[K[8;1H       r or ^R or ^L[9;8H       Repaint the screen.[10;1H[K[11;1H       R      Repaint the screen, discarding any buffered input.  Useful if the file is changing while it is being viewed.[12;1H[K[13;8HF      Scroll forward, and keep trying to read when the end of file is reached.  Normally this command would be used  when  already[14;1H              at the end of the file.  It is a way to monitor the tail of a file which is growing while it is being viewed.  (The behavior[15;8H       is similar to the "tail -f" command.)[16;1H[K[17;1H       ESC-F  Like F, but as soon as a line is found which matches the last  search  pattern,  the  terminal  bell  is  rung  and  forward[18;8H       scrolling stops.[K[20;8Hg or < or ESC-<[K[21;15HGo to line N in the file, default 1 (beginning of file).  (Warning: this may be slow if N is large.)[K[22;1H[K[23;1H       G or > or ESC->[24;8H       Go  to  line N in the file, default the end of the file.  (Warning: this may be slow if N is large, or if N is not specified[25;15Hand standard input, rather than a file, is being read.)[27;8HESC-G  Same as G, except if no number N is specified and the input is standard input, goes to the  last  line  which  is  currently[28;15Hbuffered.[K[30;8Hp or % Go to a position N percent into the file.  N should be between 0 and 100, and may contain a decimal point.[31;1H[K[32;8HP      Go to the line containing byte offset N in the file.[K[34;8H{      If  a  left curly bracket appears in the top line displayed on the screen, the { command will go to the matching right curly[35;16Hracket.  The matching right curly bracket is positioned on the bottom line of the screen.  If there is more than  one  left[36;1H              curly bracket on the top line, a number N may be used to specify the N-th bracket on the line.[36;1H[1;1H       ESC-} or ^RIGHTARROW[2;8H       Scroll horizontally right to show the end of the longest displayed line.[3;1H[K[4;1H       ESC-{ or ^LEFTARROW[5;8H       Scroll horizontally left back to the first column.[6;1H[K[7;1H       r or ^R or ^L[8;8H       Repaint the screen.[9;1H[K[10;1H       R      Repaint the screen, discarding any buffered input.  Useful if the file is changing while it is being viewed.[11;1H[K[12;1H       F      Scroll forward, and keep trying to read when the end of file is reached.  Normally this command would be used  when  already[13;8H       at the end of the file.  It is a way to monitor the tail of a file which is growing while it is being viewed.  (The behavior[14;15His similar to the "tail -f" command.)[K[15;1H[K[16;1H       ESC-F  Like F, but as soon as a line is found which matches the last  search  pattern,  the  terminal  bell  is  rung  and  forward[17;8H       scrolling stops.[K[18;1H[K[19;1H       g or < or ESC-<[20;8H       Go to line N in the file, default 1 (beginning of file).  (Warning: this may be slow if N is large.)[21;1H[K[22;1H       G or > or ESC->[23;8H       Go  to  line N in the file, default the end of the file.  (Warning: this may be slow if N is large, or if N is not specified[24;15Hand standard input, rather than a file, is being read.)[K[25;1H[K[26;1H       ESC-G  Same as G, except if no number N is specified and the input is standard input, goes to the  last  line  which  is  currently[27;8H       buffered.[K[28;1H[K[29;1H       p or % Go to a position N percent into the file.  N should be between 0 and 100, and may contain a decimal point.[30;1H[K[31;1H       P      Go to the line containing byte offset N in the file.[32;1H[K[33;1H       {      If  a  left curly bracket appears in the top line displayed on the screen, the { command will go to the matching right curly[34;8H       bracket.  The matching right curly bracket is positioned on the bottom line of the screen.  If there is more than  one  left[35;15Hcurly bracket on the top line, a number N may be used to specify the N-th bracket on the line.[K[36;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Scroll horizontally right to show the end of the longest displayed line.[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       ESC-{ or ^LEFTARROW[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Scroll horizontally left back to the first column.[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[37;1H[7m-----Info: (*manpages*)less, 1181 lines -- 7%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[0m[1;1H       r or ^R or ^L[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Repaint the screen.[36;1H[36;1H[2;1H[K[3;1H       R      Repaint the screen, discarding any buffered input.  Useful if the file is changing while it is being viewed.[4;1H[K[5;8HF      Scroll forward, and keep trying to read when the end of file is reached.  Normally this command would be used  when  already[6;1H              at the end of the file.  It is a way to monitor the tail of a file which is growing while it is being viewed. The matching right curly bracket is positioned on the bottom line of the screen.  If there is more than  one  left[28;1H              curly bracket on the top line, a number N may be used to specify the N-th bracket on the line.[29;1H[K[30;1H       }      If  a  right  curly  bracket  appears in the bottom line displayed on the screen, the } command will go to the matching left[31;8H       curly bracket.  The matching left curly bracket is positioned on the top line of the screen.  If  there  is  more  than  one[32;1H              right curly bracket on the top line, a number N may be used to specify the N-th bracket on the line.[33;1H[K[34;8H(      Like {, but applies to parentheses rather than curly brackets.[K[35;1H[K[36;1H       )      Like }, but applies to parentheses rather than curly brackets.[36;1H[1;1H[K[2;1H       R      Repaint the screen, discarding any buffered input. Followed[27;15Hby  a  ^  or $, jumps to the beginning or end of the file respectively.  Marks are preserved when a new file is examined, so[28;1H              the ' command can be used to switch between input files.[29;1H[K[30;1H       ^X^X   Same as single quote.[31;1H[K[32;8H/pattern[K[33;15HSearch forward in the file for the N-th line containing the pattern.  N defaults to 1.  The pattern is a regular expression,[34;15Has recognized by the regular expression library supplied by your system.  The search starts at the first line displayed (but[35;1H              see the -a and -j options, which change this).[36;1H[K[36;1H[1;8H       bracket.  The matching right curly bracket is positioned on the bottom line of the screen.  If there is more than  one  left[2;15Hcurly bracket on the top line, a number N may be used to specify the N-th bracket on the line.[K[3;1H[K[4;1H       }      If  a  right  curly  bracket  appears in the bottom line displayed on the screen, the } command will go to the matching left[5;8H       curly bracket.  The matching left curly bracket is positioned on the top line of the screen.  If  there  is  more  than  one[6;15Hright curly bracket on the top line, a number N may be used to specify the N-th bracket on the line.[K[7;1H[K[8;1H       (      Like {, but applies to parentheses rather than curly brackets.[9;1H[K[10;1H       )      Like }, but applies to parentheses rather than curly brackets.[11;1H[K[12;1H       [      Like {, but applies to square brackets rather than curly brackets.[13;1H[K[14;1H       ]      Like }, but applies to square brackets rather than curly brackets.[15;1H[K[16;1H       ESC-^F Followed by two characters, acts like {, but uses the two characters as open and close brackets, respectively.  For example,[17;8H       "ESC ^F < >" could be used to go forward to the > which matches the < in the top displayed line.[K[18;1H[K[19;1H       ESC-^B Followed by two characters, acts like }, but uses the two characters as open and close brackets, respectively.  For example,[20;8H       "ESC ^B < >" could be used to go backward to the < which matches the > in the bottom displayed line.[K[21;1H[K[22;1H       m      Followed by any lowercase letter, marks the current position with that letter.[23;1H[K[24;1H       '      (Single  quote.)   Followed  by  any lowercase letter, returns to the position which was previously marked with that letter.[25;8H       Followed by another single quote, returns to the position at which the last "large" movement command was executed.  Followed[26;15Hby  a  ^  or $, jumps to the beginning or end of the file respectively. That  is,  if  the search reaches the END of the current file without finding a match, the[30;22Hsearch continues in the next file in the command line list.[K[31;1H[K[32;1H              ^F or @[33;15H       Begin the search at the first line of the FIRST file in the command line list, regardless of what is  currently  dis‐[34;22Hplayed on the screen or the settings of the -a or -j options.[K[35;1H[K[36;1H              ^K     Highlight  any  text which matches the pattern on the current screen, but don't move to the first match (KEEP current[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       ESC-^F Followed by two characters, acts like {, but uses the two characters as open and close brackets, respectively.  For example,[2;8H       "ESC ^F < >" could be used to go forward to the > which matches the < in the top displayed line.[K[3;1H[K[4;1H       ESC-^B Followed by two characters, acts like }, but uses the two characters as open and close brackets, respectively.  For example,[5;8H       "ESC ^B < >" could be used to go backward to the < which matches the > in the bottom displayed line.[K[6;1H[K[7;1H       m      Followed by any lowercase letter, marks the current position with that letter.[8;1H[K[9;1H       '      (Single  quote.)   Followed  by  any lowercase letter, returns to the position which was previously marked with that letter.[10;8H       Followed by another single quote, returns to the position at which the last "large" movement command was executed.  Followed[11;15Hby  a  ^  or $, jumps to the beginning or end of the file respectively.  Marks are preserved when a new file is examined, so[12;15Hthe ' command can be used to switch between input files.[K[13;1H[K[14;1H       ^X^X   Same as single quote.[15;1H[K[16;1H       /pattern[17;8H       Search forward in the file for the N-th line containing the pattern.  N defaults to 1.  The pattern is a regular expression,[18;15Has recognized by the regular expression library supplied by your system. If the previous search was modified by ^N, the search is[32;1H              made for the N-th line NOT containing the pattern.  If the previous search was modified by ^E, the search continues  in  the[33;15Hnext (or previous) file if not satisfied in the current file. The effect is as if the previous search were modified by *.[28;1H[K[29;1H       ESC-N  Repeat previous search, but in the reverse direction and crossing file boundaries.[30;1H[K[31;8HESC-u  Undo search highlighting. Any search command will also turn highlighting back on.[33;15H(Highlighting can also be disabled by toggling the -G option; in that case search commands do  not  turn  highlighting  back[34;1H              on.)[35;1H[K[36;1H       &pattern[36;1H[1;1H              ^E or *[2;15H       Search multiple files. If the previous search was modified by ^E, the search continues  in  the[21;15Hnext (or previous) file if not satisfied in the current file.  If the previous search was modified by ^R, the search is done[22;15Hwithout using regular expressions.  There is no effect if the previous search was modified by ^F or ^K.[K[23;1H[K[24;1H       N      Repeat previous search, but in the reverse direction.[25;1H[K[26;1H       ESC-n  Repeat previous search, but crossing file boundaries.  The effect is as if the previous search were modified by *.[27;1H[K[28;1H       ESC-N  Repeat previous search, but in the reverse direction and crossing file boundaries.[29;1H[K[30;1H       ESC-u  Undo search highlighting.  Turn off highlighting of strings matching the current search pattern.  If highlighting is already[31;8H       off because of a previous ESC-u command, turn highlighting back on.  Any search command will also turn highlighting back on.[32;15H(Highlighting can also be disabled by toggling the -G option; in that case search commands do  not  turn  highlighting  back[33;15Hon.)[K[34;1H[K[35;1H       &pattern[36;8H       Display only lines which match the pattern; lines which do not match the pattern are not displayed.  If pattern is empty (if[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[37;1H[7m-----Info: (*manpages*)less, 1181 lines --15%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[0m[1;15H       Search multiple files.  That is, if the search reaches the beginning of the current file without finding a match, the[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;22Hsearch continues in the previous file in the command line list.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H              ^F or @[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15H       Begin the search at the last line of the last file in the command line list, regardless of  what  is  currently  dis‐[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;22Hplayed on the screen or the settings of the -a or -j options.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H              ^K     As in forward searches.[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H              ^R     As in forward searches.[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[2;8HESC-/pattern[K[3;15HSame as "/*".[K[5;8HESC-?pattern[K[6;15HSame as "?*".[K[7;1H[K[8;1H       n      Repeat previous search, for N-th line containing the last pattern.  If the previous search was modified by ^N, the search is[9;15Hmade for the N-th line NOT containing the pattern.  If the previous search was modified by ^E, the search continues  in  the[10;1H              next (or previous) file if not satisfied in the current file.  If the previous search was modified by ^R, the search is done[11;15Hwithout using regular expressions.  There is no effect if the previous search was modified by ^F or ^K.[13;8HN      Repeat previous search, but in the reverse direction.[14;1H[K[15;1H       ESC-n  Repeat previous search, but crossing file boundaries.  The effect is as if the previous search were modified by *.[16;1H[K[17;8HESC-N  Repeat previous search, but in the reverse direction and crossing file boundaries.[19;8HESC-u  Undo search highlighting.  Turn off highlighting of strings matching the current search pattern.  If highlighting is already[20;15Hoff because of a previous ESC-u command, turn highlighting back on.  Any search command will also turn highlighting back on.[21;15H(Highlighting can also be disabled by toggling the -G option; in that case search commands do  not  turn  highlighting  back[22;15Hon.)[K[24;8H&pattern[K[25;1H              Display only lines which match the pattern; lines which do not match the pattern are not displayed.  If pattern is empty (if[26;8H       you type & immediately followed by ENTER), any filtering is turned off, and all lines are displayed.  While filtering is  in[27;1H              effect, an ampersand is displayed at the beginning of the prompt, as a reminder that some lines in the file may be hidden.[28;1H[K[29;1H              Certain characters are special as in the / command:[30;1H[K[31;15H^N or ![K[32;15H       Display only lines which do NOT match the pattern.[K[33;1H[K[34;1H              ^R     Don't interpret regular expression metacharacters; that is, do a simple textual comparison.[35;1H[K[36;8H:e [filename][K[36;1H[1;1H       ESC-/pattern[2;8H       Same as "/*".[3;1H[K[4;1H       ESC-?pattern[5;8H       Same as "?*".[6;1H[K[7;1H       n      Repeat previous search, for N-th line containing the last pattern.  If the previous search was modified by ^N, the search is[8;8H       made for the N-th line NOT containing the pattern.  If the previous search was modified by ^E, the search continues  in  the[9;15Hnext (or previous) file if not satisfied in the current file. A percent sign (%) in the filename is replaced by the name of the  current  file.[28;15HA pound sign (#) is replaced by the name of the previously examined file.  However, two consecutive percent signs are simply[29;1H              replaced with a single percent sign.  This allows you to enter a filename that contains a percent sign in the  name. If  the filename is missing, the "current" file (see the :n and :p commands below) from the list of[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hfiles in the command line is re-examined.  A percent sign (%) in the filename is replaced by the name of the  current  file.[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15HA pound sign (#) is replaced by the name of the previously examined file.  However, two consecutive percent signs are simply[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hreplaced with a single percent sign.  This allows you to enter a filename that contains a percent sign in the  name.   Simi‐[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hlarly,  two  consecutive  pound signs are replaced with a single pound sign.  The filename is inserted into the command line[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;16Hist of files so that it can be seen by subsequent :n and :p commands.  If the filename consists of several files, they  are[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hall  inserted into the list of files and the first one is examined.  If the filename contains one or more spaces, the entire[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hfilename should be enclosed in double quotes (also see the -" option).[K[36;1H[36;1H[2;1H[K[3;8H^X^V or E[K[4;15HSame as :e.  Warning: some systems use ^V as a special literalization character.  On such systems, you may not  be  able  to[5;15Huse ^V.[K[6;1H[K[7;8H:n     Examine the next file (from the list of files given in the command line).  If a number N is specified, the N-th next file is[8;15Hexamined.[K[9;1H[K[10;1H       :p     Examine the previous file in the command line list.  If a number N is specified, the N-th previous file is examined.[11;1H[K[12;8H:x     Examine the first file in the command line list.  If a number N is specified, the N-th file in the list is examined.[K[13;1H[K[14;1H       :d     Remove the current file from the list of files.[15;1H[K[16;8Ht      Go to the next tag, if there were more than one matches for the current tag.  See the -t option for more details about tags.[18;8HT      Go to the previous tag, if there were more than one matches for the current tag.[K[20;8H= or ^G or :f[K[21;1H              Prints some information about the file being viewed, including its name and the line number and byte offset  of  the  bottom[22;8H       line  being  displayed.  If possible, it also prints the length of the file, the number of lines in the file and the percent[23;1H              of the file above the last displayed line.[24;1H[K[25;1H       -      Followed by one of the command line option letters (see OPTIONS below), this will change the  setting  of  that  option  and[26;8H       print  a  message describing the new setting.  If a ^P (CONTROL-P) is entered immediately after the dash, the setting of the[27;1H              option is changed but no message is printed.  If the option letter has a numeric value (such as -b or -h), or a string value[28;8H       (such  as  -P  or -t), a new value may be entered after the option letter.  If no new value is entered, a message describing[29;15Hthe current setting is printed and nothing is changed.[K[30;1H[K[31;8H--     Like the - command, but takes a long option name (see OPTIONS below) rather than a single option  letter.   You  must  press[32;1H              ENTER  or  RETURN  after  typing  the  option name.  A ^P immediately after the second dash suppresses printing of a message[33;8H       describing the new setting, as in the - command.[K[34;1H[K[35;8H-+     Followed by one of the command line option letters this will reset the option to its default setting  and  print  a  message[36;15Hdescribing  the  new setting.  (The "-+X" command does the same thing as "-+X" on the command line.)  This does not work for[36;1H[1;1H[K[2;1H       ^X^V or E[3;8H       Same as :e.  Warning: some systems use ^V as a special literalization character.  On such systems, you may not  be  able  to[4;15Huse ^V.[K[5;1H[K[6;1H       :n     Examine the next file (from the list of files given in the command line).  If a number N is specified, the N-th next file is[7;8H       examined.[K[8;1H[K[9;1H       :p     Examine the previous file in the command line list.  If a number N is specified, the N-th previous file is examined.[10;1H[K[11;1H       :x     Examine the first file in the command line list.  If a number N is specified, the N-th file in the list is examined.[12;1H[K[13;1H       :d     Remove the current file from the list of files.[14;1H[K[15;1H       t      Go to the next tag, if there were more than one matches for the current tag.  See the -t option for more details about tags.[16;1H[K[17;1H       T      Go to the previous tag, if there were more than one matches for the current tag.[18;1H[K[19;1H       = or ^G or :f[20;8H       Prints some information about the file being viewed, including its name and the line number and byte offset  of  the  bottom[21;15Hline  being  displayed.  If possible, it also prints the length of the file, the number of lines in the file and the percent[22;15Hof the file above the last displayed line.[K[23;1H[K[24;1H       -      Followed by one of the command line option letters (see OPTIONS below), this will change the  setting  of  that  option  and[25;8H       print  a  message describing the new setting. If the option letter has a numeric value (such as -b or -h), or a string value[27;15H(such  as  -P  or -t), a new value may be entered after the option letter.  If no new value is entered, a message describing[28;15Hthe current setting is printed and nothing is changed.[K[29;1H[K[30;1H       --     Like the - command, but takes a long option name (see OPTIONS below) rather than a single option  letter. You[30;1H              must press ENTER or RETURN after typing the option name.[31;1H[K[32;8H+cmd   Causes  the specified cmd to be executed each time a new file is examined.  For example, +G causes less to initially display[33;1H              each file starting at the end rather than the beginning.[34;1H[K[35;8HV      Prints the version number of less being run.[K[36;1H[1;15Hline  being  displayed.  If possible, it also prints the length of the file, the number of lines in the file and the percent[2;15Hof the file above the last displayed line.[K[3;1H[K[4;1H       -      Followed by one of the command line option letters (see OPTIONS below), this will change the  setting  of  that  option  and[5;8H       print  a  message describing the new setting.  If a ^P (CONTROL-P) is entered immediately after the dash, the setting of the[6;15Hoption is changed but no message is printed.  If the option letter has a numeric value (such as -b or -h), or a string value[7;15H(such  as  -P  or -t), a new value may be entered after the option letter.  If no new value is entered, a message describing[8;15Hthe current setting is printed and nothing is changed.[K[9;1H[K[10;1H       --     Like the - command, but takes a long option name (see OPTIONS below) rather than a single option  letter.   You  must  press[11;8H       ENTER  or  RETURN  after  typing  the  option name.  A ^P immediately after the second dash suppresses printing of a message[12;15Hdescribing the new setting, as in the - command.[K[13;1H[K[14;1H       -+     Followed by one of the command line option letters this will reset the option to its default setting  and  print  a  message[15;8H       describing  the  new setting.  (The "-+X" command does the same thing as "-+X" on the command line.)  This does not work for[16;15Hstring-valued options.[K[17;1H[K[18;1H       --+    Like the -+ command, but takes a long option name rather than a single option letter.[19;1H[K[20;1H       -! If <m> is . or newline, the current screen is piped.[K[24;1H[K[25;8Hs filename[K[26;15HSave the input to a file.  This only works if the input is a pipe, not an ordinary file.[K[28;1HOPTIONS[K[29;8HCommand line options are described below.  Most options may be changed while less is running, via the "-" command.[K[30;1H[K[31;8HMost  options  may be given in one of two forms: either a dash followed by a single letter, or two dashes followed by a long option[32;1H       name.  A long option name may be abbreviated as long as the abbreviation is unambiguous.  For example, --quit-at-eof may be  abbre‐[33;8Hviated --quit, but not --qui, since both --quit-at-eof and --quiet begin with --qui.  Some long option names are in uppercase, such[34;8Has --QUIT-AT-EOF, as distinct from --quit-at-eof.  Such option names need only have their first letter capitalized;  the  remainder[35;1H       of the name may be in either case.  For example, --Quit-at-eof is equivalent to --QUIT-AT-EOF.[36;1H[K[36;1H[1;1H[K[2;1H       V      Prints the version number of less being run.[3;1H[K[4;1H       q or Q or :q or :Q or ZZ[5;8H       Exits less.[K[6;1H[K[7;1H       The following four commands may or may not be valid, depending on your particular installation.[8;1H[K[9;1H       v      Invokes an editor to edit the current file being viewed.  The editor is  taken  from  the  environment  variable  VISUAL  if[10;8H       defined, or EDITOR if VISUAL is not defined, or defaults to "vi" if neither VISUAL nor EDITOR is defined.  See also the dis‐[11;15Hcussion of LESSEDIT under the section on PROMPTS below.[K[12;1H[K[13;1H       ! shell-command[14;8H       Invokes a shell to run the shell-command given.  A percent sign (%) in the command is replaced by the name  of  the  current[15;15Hfile.   A pound sign (#) is replaced by the name of the previously examined file.  "!!" repeats the last shell command.  "!"[16;15Hwith no shell command simply invokes a shell.  On Unix systems, the shell is taken from the environment variable  SHELL,  or[17;15Hdefaults to "sh".  On MS-DOS and OS/2 systems, the shell is the normal command processor.[K[18;1H[K[19;1H       | <m> shell-command[20;8H       <m>  represents  any mark letter.  Pipes a section of the input file to the given shell command.  The section of the file to[21;15Hbe piped is between the first line on the current screen and the position marked by the letter.  <m> may also be ^ or  $  to[22;15Hindicate beginning or end of file respectively.  If <m> is . or newline, the current screen is piped.[K[23;1H[K[24;1H       s filename[25;8H       Save the input to a file.  This only works if the input is a pipe, not an ordinary file.[26;1H[K[27;1HOPTIONS[28;1H       Command line options are described below.  Most options may be changed while less is running, via the "-" command.[29;1H[K[30;1H       Most  options  may be given in one of two forms: either a dash followed by a single letter, or two dashes followed by a long option[31;8Hname.  A long option name may be abbreviated as long as the abbreviation is unambiguous.  For example, --quit-at-eof may be  abbre‐[32;8Hviated --quit, but not --qui, since both --quit-at-eof and --quiet begin with --qui.  Some long option names are in uppercase, such[33;8Has --QUIT-AT-EOF, as distinct from --quit-at-eof.  Such option names need only have their first letter capitalized;  the  remainder[34;8Hof the name may be in either case.  For example, --Quit-at-eof is equivalent to --QUIT-AT-EOF.[K[35;1H[K[36;1H       Options  are  also  taken from the environment variable "LESS".  For example, to avoid typing "less -options ..." each time less is[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       V      Prints the version number of less being run.[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       q or Q or :q or :Q or ZZ[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Exits less.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       The following four commands may or may not be valid, depending on your particular installation.[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[2;8Hv      Invokes an editor to edit the current file being viewed.  The editor is  taken  from  the  environment  variable  VISUAL  if[3;1H              defined, or EDITOR if VISUAL is not defined, or defaults to "vi" if neither VISUAL nor EDITOR is defined.  See also the dis‐[4;8H       cussion of LESSEDIT under the section on PROMPTS below.[5;1H[K[6;1H       ! shell-command[7;8H       Invokes a shell to run the shell-command given.  A percent sign (%) in the command is replaced by the name  of  the  current[8;1H              file.   A pound sign (#) is replaced by the name of the previously examined file.  "!!" repeats the last shell command.  "!"[9;8H       with no shell command simply invokes a shell.  On Unix systems, the shell is taken from the environment variable  SHELL,  or[10;18Haults to "sh".  On MS-DOS and OS/2 systems, the shell is the normal command processor.[K[11;1H[K[12;1H       | <m> shell-command[13;8H       <m>  represents  any mark letter.  Pipes a section of the input file to the given shell command.  The section of the file to[14;15Hbe piped is between the first line on the current screen and the position marked by the letter.  <m> may also be ^ or  $  to[15;15Hindicate beginning or end of file respectively.  If <m> is . or newline, the current screen is piped.[K[16;1H[K[17;8Hs filename[K[18;1H              Save the input to a file.  This only works if the input is a pipe, not an ordinary file.[19;1H[K[20;1HOPTIONS[K[21;8HCommand line options are described below.  Most options may be changed while less is running, via the "-" command.[K[22;1H[K[23;1H       Most  options  may be given in one of two forms: either a dash followed by a single letter, or two dashes followed by a long option[24;8Hname.  A long option name may be abbreviated as long as the abbreviation is unambiguous.  For example, --quit-at-eof may be  abbre‐[25;8Hviated --quit, but not --qui, since both --quit-at-eof and --quiet begin with --qui.  Some long option names are in uppercase, such[26;1H       as --QUIT-AT-EOF, as distinct from --quit-at-eof.  Such option names need only have their first letter capitalized;  the  remainder[27;1H       of the name may be in either case.  For example, --Quit-at-eof is equivalent to --QUIT-AT-EOF.[28;1H[K[29;1H       Options  are  also  taken from the environment variable "LESS".  For example, to avoid typing "less -options ..." each time less is[30;8Hinvoked, you might tell csh:[K[31;1H[K[32;8Hsetenv LESS "-options"[K[33;1H[K[34;9Hr if you use sh:[K[36;8HLESS="-options"; export LESS[K[36;1H[1;1H       v      Invokes an editor to edit the current file being viewed.  The editor is  taken  from  the  environment  variable  VISUAL  if[2;8H       defined, or EDITOR if VISUAL is not defined, or defaults to "vi" if neither VISUAL nor EDITOR is defined.  See also the dis‐[3;15Hcussion of LESSEDIT under the section on PROMPTS below.[K[4;1H[K[5;1H       ! shell-command[6;8H       Invokes a shell to run the shell-command given.  A percent sign (%) in the command is replaced by the name  of  the  current[7;15Hfile.   A pound sign (#) is replaced by the name of the previously examined file.  "!!" repeats the last shell command.  "!"[8;15Hwith no shell command simply invokes a shell.  On Unix systems, the shell is taken from the environment variable  SHELL,  or[9;15Hdefaults to "sh".  On MS-DOS and OS/2 systems, the shell is the normal command processor.[K[10;1H[K[11;1H       | <m> shell-command[12;8H       <m>  represents  any mark letter. If <m> is . or newline, the current screen is piped.[K[15;1H[K[16;1H       s filename[17;8H       Save the input to a file.  This only works if the input is a pipe, not an ordinary file.[18;1H[K[19;1HOPTIONS[20;1H       Command line options are described below.  Most options may be changed while less is running, via the "-" command.[21;1H[K[22;1H       Most  options  may be given in one of two forms: either a dash followed by a single letter, or two dashes followed by a long option[23;8Hname.  A long option name may be abbreviated as long as the abbreviation is unambiguous.  For example, --quit-at-eof may be  abbre‐[24;8Hviated --quit, but not --qui, since both --quit-at-eof and --quiet begin with --qui.  Some long option names are in uppercase, such[25;8Has --QUIT-AT-EOF, as distinct from --quit-at-eof.  Such option names need only have their first letter capitalized;  the  remainder[26;8Hof the name may be in either case.  For example, --Quit-at-eof is equivalent to --QUIT-AT-EOF.[K[27;1H[K[28;1H       Options  are  also  taken from the environment variable "LESS". A long option name may be abbreviated as long as the abbreviation is unambiguous.  For example, --quit-at-eof may be  abbre‐[16;8Hviated --quit, but not --qui, since both --quit-at-eof and --quiet begin with --qui. Such option names need only have their first letter capitalized;  the  remainder[18;1H       of the name may be in either case.  For example, --Quit-at-eof is equivalent to --QUIT-AT-EOF.[19;1H[K[20;8HOptions  are  also  taken from the environment variable "LESS".  For example, to avoid typing "less -options ..." each time less is[21;1H       invoked, you might tell csh:[22;1H[K[23;8Hsetenv LESS "-options"[K[24;1H[K[25;8Hor if you use sh:[K[26;1H[K[27;1H       LESS="-options"; export LESS[28;1H[K[29;8HOn MS-DOS, you don't need the quotes, but you should replace any percent signs in the options string by double percent signs.[31;8HThe environment variable is parsed before the command line, so command line options override the LESS environment variable.  If  an[32;1H       option  appears in the LESS variable, it can be reset to its default value on the command line by beginning the command line option[33;8Hwith "-+".[K[35;8HSome options like -k or -D require a string to follow the option letter.  The string for that option is considered to  end  when  a[36;1H       dollar sign ($) is found.  For example, you can set two -D options on MS-DOS like this:[36;1H[1;1H[K[2;1H       | <m> shell-command[3;8H       <m>  represents  any mark letter. If <m> is . or newline, the current screen is piped.[K[6;1H[K[7;1H       s filename[8;8H       Save the input to a file.  This only works if the input is a pipe, not an ordinary file.[9;1H[K[10;1HOPTIONS[11;1H       Command line options are described below.  Most options may be changed while less is running, via the "-" command.[12;1H[K[13;1H       Most  options  may be given in one of two forms: either a dash followed by a single letter, or two dashes followed by a long option[14;8Hname.  A long option name may be abbreviated as long as the abbreviation is unambiguous.  For example, --quit-at-eof may be  abbre‐[15;8Hviated --quit, but not --qui, since both --quit-at-eof and --quiet begin with --qui.  Some long option names are in uppercase, such[16;8Has --QUIT-AT-EOF, as distinct from --quit-at-eof.  Such option names need only have their first letter capitalized;  the  remainder[17;8Hof the name may be in either case.  For example, --Quit-at-eof is equivalent to --QUIT-AT-EOF.[K[18;1H[K[19;1H       Options  are  also  taken from the environment variable "LESS".  For example, to avoid typing "less -options ..." each time less is[20;8Hinvoked, you might tell csh:[K[21;1H[K[22;1H       setenv LESS "-options"[23;1H[K[24;1H       or if you use sh:[25;1H[K[26;1H       LESS="-options"; export LESS[27;1H[K[28;1H       On MS-DOS, you don't need the quotes, but you should replace any percent signs in the options string by double percent signs.[29;1H[K[30;1H       The environment variable is parsed before the command line, so command line options override the LESS environment variable.  If  an[31;8Hoption  appears in the LESS variable, it can be reset to its default value on the command line by beginning the command line option[32;8Hwith "-+".[K[33;1H[K[34;1H       Some options like -k or -D require a string to follow the option letter.  The string for that option is considered to  end  when  a[35;8Hdollar sign ($) is found.  For example, you can set two -D options on MS-DOS like this:[K[36;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       | <m> shell-command[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       <m>  represents  any mark letter. If <m> is . or newline, the current screen is piped.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       s filename[36;1H[36;1H[2;8H       Save the input to a file.  This only works if the input is a pipe, not an ordinary file.[3;1H[K[4;1HOPTIONS[K[5;8HCommand line options are described below.  Most options may be changed while less is running, via the "-" command.[7;8HMost  options  may be given in one of two forms: either a dash followed by a single letter, or two dashes followed by a long option[8;8Hname.  A long option name may be abbreviated as long as the abbreviation is unambiguous.  For example, --quit-at-eof may be  abbre‐[9;1H       viated --quit, but not --qui, since both --quit-at-eof and --quiet begin with --qui.  Some long option names are in uppercase, such[10;1H       as --QUIT-AT-EOF, as distinct from --quit-at-eof.  Such option names need only have their first letter capitalized;  the  remainder[11;8Hof the name may be in either case.  For example, --Quit-at-eof is equivalent to --QUIT-AT-EOF.[K[13;8HOptions  are  also  taken from the environment variable "LESS".  For example, to avoid typing "less -options ..." each time less is[14;8Hinvoked, you might tell csh:[K[15;1H[K[16;8Hsetenv LESS "-options"[K[17;1H[K[18;1H       or if you use sh:[19;1H[K[20;8HLESS="-options"; export LESS[22;8HOn MS-DOS, you don't need the quotes, but you should replace any percent signs in the options string by double percent signs.[24;8HThe environment variable is parsed before the command line, so command line options override the LESS environment variable.  If  an[25;1H       option  appears in the LESS variable, it can be reset to its default value on the command line by beginning the command line option[26;8Hwith "-+".[K[28;8HSome options like -k or -D require a string to follow the option letter.  The string for that option is considered to  end  when  a[29;1H       dollar sign ($) is found.  For example, you can set two -D options on MS-DOS like this:[30;1H[K[31;8HLESS="Dn9.1$Ds4.1"[K[32;1H[K[33;1H       If  the  --use-backslash  option  appears  earlier  in the options, then a dollar sign or backslash may be included literally in an[34;8Hoption string by preceding it with a backslash.  If the --use-backslash option is not in effect, then backslashes are  not  treated[35;8Hspecially, and there is no way to include a dollar sign in the option string.[K[36;1H[1;8H       Save the input to a file.  This only works if the input is a pipe, not an ordinary file.[2;1H[K[3;1HOPTIONS[4;1H       Command line options are described below.  Most options may be changed while less is running, via the "-" command.[5;1H[K[6;1H       Most  options  may be given in one of two forms: either a dash followed by a single letter, or two dashes followed by a long option[7;8Hname.  A long option name may be abbreviated as long as the abbreviation is unambiguous.  For example, --quit-at-eof may be  abbre‐[8;8Hviated --quit, but not --qui, since both --quit-at-eof and --quiet begin with --qui.  Some long option names are in uppercase, such[9;8Has --QUIT-AT-EOF, as distinct from --quit-at-eof.  Such option names need only have their first letter capitalized;  the  remainder[10;8Hof the name may be in either case.  For example, --Quit-at-eof is equivalent to --QUIT-AT-EOF.[K[11;1H[K[12;1H       Options  are  also  taken from the environment variable "LESS".  For example, to avoid typing "less -options ..." each time less is[13;8Hinvoked, you might tell csh:[K[14;1H[K[15;1H       setenv LESS "-options"[16;1H[K[17;1H       or if you use sh:[18;1H[K[19;1H       LESS="-options"; export LESS[20;1H[K[21;1H       On MS-DOS, you don't need the quotes, but you should replace any percent signs in the options string by double percent signs.[22;1H[K[23;1H       The environment variable is parsed before the command line, so command line options override the LESS environment variable.  If  an[24;8Hoption  appears in the LESS variable, it can be reset to its default value on the command line by beginning the command line option[25;8Hwith "-+".[K[26;1H[K[27;1H       Some options like -k or -D require a string to follow the option letter.  The string for that option is considered to  end  when  a[28;8Hdollar sign ($) is found.  For example, you can set two -D options on MS-DOS like this:[K[29;1H[K[30;1H       LESS="Dn9.1$Ds4.1"[31;1H[K[32;1H       If  the  --use-backslash  option  appears  earlier  in the options, then a dollar sign or backslash may be included literally in an[33;8Hoption string by preceding it with a backslash.  If the --use-backslash option is not in effect, then backslashes are  not  treated[34;8Hspecially, and there is no way to include a dollar sign in the option string.[K[35;1H[K[36;1H       -? or --help[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1HOPTIONS[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       Command line options are described below. The string for that option is considered to  end  when  a[16;8Hdollar sign ($) is found.  For example, you can set two -D options on MS-DOS like this:[K[17;1H[K[18;8HLESS="Dn9.1$Ds4.1"[20;8HIf  the  --use-backslash  option  appears  earlier  in the options, then a dollar sign or backslash may be included literally in an[21;8Hoption string by preceding it with a backslash.  If the --use-backslash option is not in effect, then backslashes are  not  treated[22;1H       specially, and there is no way to include a dollar sign in the option string.[23;1H[K[24;1H       -? or --help[25;8H       This  option  displays a summary of the commands accepted by less (the same as the h command).  (Depending on how your shell[26;8H       interprets the question mark, it may be necessary to quote the question mark, thus: "-\?".)[K[27;1H[K[28;1H       -a or --search-skip-screen[29;8H       By default, forward searches start at the top of the displayed screen and backwards searches start at the bottom of the dis‐[30;15Hplayed  screen  (except  for repeated searches invoked by the n or N commands, which start after or before the "target" line[31;15Hrespectively; see the -j option for more about the target line).  The -a option causes forward searches to instead start  at[32;1H              the  bottom  of the screen and backward searches to start at the top of the screen, thus skipping all lines displayed on the[33;8H       screen.[K[34;1H[K[35;8H-A or --SEARCH-SKIP-SCREEN[K[36;15HCauses all forward searches (not just non-repeated searches) to start just after the target line, and all backward  searches[36;1H[1;1H[K[2;1H       setenv LESS "-options"[3;1H[K[4;1H       or if you use sh:[5;1H[K[6;1H       LESS="-options"; export LESS[7;1H[K[8;1H       On MS-DOS, you don't need the quotes, but you should replace any percent signs in the options string by double percent signs.[9;1H[K[10;1H       The environment variable is parsed before the command line, so command line options override the LESS environment variable.  If  an[11;8Hoption  appears in the LESS variable, it can be reset to its default value on the command line by beginning the command line option[12;8Hwith "-+".[K[13;1H[K[14;1H       Some options like -k or -D require a string to follow the option letter.  The string for that option is considered to  end  when  a[15;8Hdollar sign ($) is found. This was the default behavior in less versions prior to 441.[K[26;1H[K[27;8H-bn or --buffers=n[28;1H              Specifies  the  amount  of buffer space less will use for each file, in units of kilobytes (1024 bytes).  By default 64 K of[29;8H       buffer space is used for each file (unless the file is a pipe; see the -B option).  The -b option specifies instead  that  n[30;15Hkilobytes of buffer space should be used for each file.  If n is -1, buffer space is unlimited; that is, the entire file can[31;15Hbe read into memory.[K[32;1H[K[33;8H-B or --auto-buffers[K[34;1H              By default, when data is read from a pipe, buffers are allocated automatically as needed.  If a large amount of data is read[35;8H       from the pipe, this can cause a large amount of memory to be allocated.  The -B option disables this automatic allocation of[36;15Hbuffers for pipes, so that only 64 K (or the amount of space specified by the -b option) is used for the pipe. The -d option does not otherwise change the behavior of[32;15Hless on a dumb terminal.[K[34;9HDxcolor or --color=xcolor[35;15H[MS-DOS  only]  Sets the color of the text displayed.  x is a single character which selects the type of text whose color is[36;1H              being set: n=normal, s=standout, d=bold, u=underlined, k=blink.  color is a pair of numbers  separated  by  a  period.   The[36;1H[1;1H[K[2;1H       -A or --SEARCH-SKIP-SCREEN[3;8H       Causes all forward searches (not just non-repeated searches) to start just after the target line, and all backward  searches[4;15Hto start just before the target line.  Thus, forward searches will skip part of the displayed screen (from the first line up[5;18Hand including the target line).  Similarly backwards searches will skip the displayed screen from the last line up to and[6;15Hincluding the target line.  This was the default behavior in less versions prior to 441.[K[7;1H[K[8;1H       -bn or --buffers=n[9;8H       Specifies  the  amount  of buffer space less will use for each file, in units of kilobytes (1024 bytes).  By default 64 K of[10;15Hbuffer space is used for each file (unless the file is a pipe; see the -B option).  The -b option specifies instead  that  n[11;15Hkilobytes of buffer space should be used for each file.  If n is -1, buffer space is unlimited; that is, the entire file can[12;15Hbe read into memory.[K[13;1H[K[14;1H       -B or --auto-buffers[15;8H       By default, when data is read from a pipe, buffers are allocated automatically as needed.  If a large amount of data is read[16;15Hfrom the pipe, this can cause a large amount of memory to be allocated.  The -B option disables this automatic allocation of[17;15Hbuffers for pipes, so that only 64 K (or the amount of space specified by the -b option) is used for the pipe.  Warning: use[18;15Hof  -B  can  result  in erroneous display, since only the most recently viewed part of the piped data is kept in memory; any[19;15Hearlier data is lost.[K[20;1H[K[21;1H       -c or --clear-screen[22;8H       Causes full screen repaints to be painted from the top line down.  By default, full screen repaints are  done  by  scrolling[23;15Hfrom the bottom of the screen.[K[24;1H[K[25;1H       -C or --CLEAR-SCREEN[26;8H       Same as -c, for compatibility with older versions of less.[27;1H[K[28;1H       -d or --dumb[29;8H       The  -d  option suppresses the error message normally displayed if the terminal is dumb; that is, lacks some important capa‐[30;15Hbility, such as the ability to clear the screen or scroll backward.  The -d option does not otherwise change the behavior of[31;15Hless on a dumb terminal.[K[32;1H[K[33;1H       -Dxcolor or --color=xcolor[34;8H       [MS-DOS  only]  Sets the color of the text displayed.  x is a single character which selects the type of text whose color is[35;15Hbeing set: n=normal, s=standout, d=bold, u=underlined, k=blink.  color is a pair of numbers  separated  by  a  period.   The[36;15Hfirst number selects the foreground color and the second selects the background color of the text.  A single number N is the[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       -A or --SEARCH-SKIP-SCREEN[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Causes all forward searches (not just non-repeated searches) to start just after the target line, and all backward  searches[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hto start just before the target line.  Thus, forward searches will skip part of the displayed screen (from the first line up[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;18Hand including the target line).  Similarly backwards searches will skip the displayed screen from the last line up to and[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hincluding the target line.  This was the default behavior in less versions prior to 441.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       -bn or --buffers=n[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[37;1H[7m-----Info: (*manpages*)less, 1181 lines --31%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[0m[1;8H       Specifies  the  amount  of buffer space less will use for each file, in units of kilobytes (1024 bytes).  By default 64 K of[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hbuffer space is used for each file (unless the file is a pipe; see the -B option).  The -b option specifies instead  that  n[36;1H[36;1H[2;8H       kilobytes of buffer space should be used for each file.  If n is -1, buffer space is unlimited; that is, the entire file can[3;15Hbe read into memory.[K[4;1H[K[5;8H-B or --auto-buffers[K[6;15HBy default, when data is read from a pipe, buffers are allocated automatically as needed.  If a large amount of data is read[7;1H              from the pipe, this can cause a large amount of memory to be allocated.  The -B option disables this automatic allocation of[8;8H       buffers for pipes, so that only 64 K (or the amount of space specified by the -b option) is used for the pipe.  Warning: use[9;15Hof  -B  can  result  in erroneous display, since only the most recently viewed part of the piped data is kept in memory; any[10;15Hearlier data is lost.[K[11;1H[K[12;8H-c or --clear-screen[K[13;1H              Causes full screen repaints to be painted from the top line down.  By default, full screen repaints are  done  by  scrolling[14;8H       from the bottom of the screen.[15;1H[K[16;8H-C or --CLEAR-SCREEN[K[17;15HSame as -c, for compatibility with older versions of less.[K[18;1H[K[19;8H-d or --dumb[K[20;1H              The  -d  option suppresses the error message normally displayed if the terminal is dumb; that is, lacks some important capa‐[21;8H       bility, such as the ability to clear the screen or scroll backward.  The -d option does not otherwise change the behavior of[22;15Hless on a dumb terminal.[K[23;1H[K[24;1H       -Dxcolor or --color=xcolor[25;8H       [MS-DOS  only]  Sets the color of the text displayed.  x is a single character which selects the type of text whose color is[26;15Hbeing set: n=normal, s=standout, d=bold, u=underlined, k=blink.  color is a pair of numbers  separated  by  a  period.   The[27;1H              first number selects the foreground color and the second selects the background color of the text.  A single number N is the[28;8H       same as N.M, where M is the normal background color.  x may also be a to toggle strict ANSI sequence rendering (SGR mode).[29;1H[K[30;8H-e or --quit-at-eof[K[31;15HCauses less to automatically exit the second time it reaches end-of-file.  By default, the only way to exit less is via  the[32;1H              "q" command.[33;1H[K[34;8H-E or --QUIT-AT-EOF[K[35;15HCauses less to automatically exit the first time it reaches end-of-file.[K[36;1H[K[36;1H[1;15Hkilobytes of buffer space should be used for each file. This can cause less  to  run  somewhat  faster[28;15Hthan the default.[K[29;1H[K[30;1H       -G or --HILITE-SEARCH[31;8H       The -G option suppresses all highlighting of strings found by search commands.[32;1H[K[33;1H       -hn or --max-back-scroll=n[34;8H       Specifies a maximum number of lines to scroll backward. (If the terminal does  not  have  the  ability  to  scroll  backward,  -h0  is[36;15Himplied.)[K[36;1H[1;15Hless on a dumb terminal.[K[2;1H[K[3;1H       -Dxcolor or --color=xcolor[4;8H       [MS-DOS  only]  Sets the color of the text displayed.  x is a single character which selects the type of text whose color is[5;15Hbeing set: n=normal, s=standout, d=bold, u=underlined, k=blink.  color is a pair of numbers  separated  by  a  period. (A non-regular file is a directory or a device special file.)  Also suppresses the[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hwarning message when a binary file is opened.  By default, less will refuse to open non-regular files.  Note that some oper‐[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hating systems will not allow directories to be read, even if -f is set.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       -F or --quit-if-one-screen[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Causes less to automatically exit if the entire file can be displayed on the first screen.[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       -g or --hilite-search[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[37;1H[7m-----Info: (*manpages*)less, 1181 lines --35%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[0m[1;8H       Normally, less will highlight ALL strings which match the last search command.  The -g option changes this behavior to high‐[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hlight only the particular string which was found by the last search command.  This can cause less  to  run  somewhat  faster[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hthan the default.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       -G or --HILITE-SEARCH[36;1H[36;1H[2;1H              The -G option suppresses all highlighting of strings found by search commands.[3;1H[K[4;8H-hn or --max-back-scroll=n[K[5;15HSpecifies a maximum number of lines to scroll backward.  If it is necessary to scroll backward more than n lines, the screen[6;15His repainted in a forward direction instead.  (If the terminal does  not  have  the  ability  to  scroll  backward,  -h0  is[7;15Himplied.)[K[9;9Hi or --ignore-case[10;22H searches  to  ignore case; that is, uppercase and lowercase are considered identical.  This option is ignored if any[11;15Huppercase letters appear in the search pattern; in other words, if a pattern contains uppercase letters,  then  that  search[12;1H              does not ignore case.[13;1H[K[14;8H-I or --IGNORE-CASE[K[15;1H              Like -i, but searches ignore case even if the pattern contains uppercase letters.[16;1H[K[17;8H-jn or --jump-target=n[K[18;15HSpecifies  a  line  on the screen where the "target" line is to be positioned.  The target line is the line specified by any[19;15Hcommand to search for a pattern, jump to a line number, jump to a file percentage or jump to a tag.  The screen line may  be[20;1H              specified  by  a number: the top line on the screen is 1, the next is 2, and so on.  The number may be negative to specify a[21;8H       line relative to the bottom of the screen: the bottom line on the screen is -1, the second to the bottom is -2, and  so  on.[22;15HAlternately,  the  screen line may be specified as a fraction of the height of the screen, starting with a decimal point: .5[23;1H              is in the middle of the screen, .3 is three tenths down from the first line, and so on.  If the line is specified as a frac‐[24;8H       tion, the actual line number is recalculated if the terminal window is resized, so that the target line remains at the spec‐[25;15Hified fraction of the screen height.  If any form of the -j option is used, repeated forward searches (invoked with  "n"  or[26;15H"N")  begin  at  the line immediately after the target line, and repeated backward searches begin at the target line, unless[27;15Hchanged by -a or -A.  For example, if "-j4" is used, the target line is the fourth line on the screen, so  forward  searches[28;1H              begin at the fifth line on the screen.  However nonrepeated searches (invoked with "/" or "?")  always begin at the start or[29;8H       end of the current screen respectively.[30;1H[K[31;1H       -J or --status-column[32;8H       Displays a status column at the left edge of the screen.  The status column shows the lines that matched the current search.[33;15HThe status column is also used if the -w or -W option is in effect.[K[34;1H[K[35;8H-kfilename or --lesskey-file=filename[36;1H              Causes  less  to  open  and  interpret  the named file as a lesskey (1) file.  Multiple -k options may be specified.  If the[36;1H[1;8H       The -G option suppresses all highlighting of strings found by search commands.[2;1H[K[3;1H       -hn or --max-back-scroll=n[4;8H       Specifies a maximum number of lines to scroll backward.  If it is necessary to scroll backward more than n lines, the screen[5;15His repainted in a forward direction instead.  (If the terminal does  not  have  the  ability  to  scroll  backward,  -h0  is[6;16Hmplied.)[K[7;1H[K[8;1H       -i or --ignore-case[9;8H       Causes  searches  to  ignore case; that is, uppercase and lowercase are considered identical.  This option is ignored if any[10;15Huppercase letters appear in the search pattern; in other words, if a pattern contains uppercase letters,  then  that  search[11;15Hdoes not ignore case.[K[12;1H[K[13;1H       -I or --IGNORE-CASE[14;8H       Like -i, but searches ignore case even if the pattern contains uppercase letters.[15;1H[K[16;1H       -jn or --jump-target=n[17;8H       Specifies  a  line  on the screen where the "target" line is to be positioned.  The target line is the line specified by any[18;15Hcommand to search for a pattern, jump to a line number, jump to a file percentage or jump to a tag.  The screen line may  be[19;15Hspecified  by  a number: the top line on the screen is 1, the next is 2, and so on.  The number may be negative to specify a[20;15Hline relative to the bottom of the screen: the bottom line on the screen is -1, the second to the bottom is -2, and  so  on.[21;15HAlternately,  the  screen line may be specified as a fraction of the height of the screen, starting with a decimal point: .5[22;15His in the middle of the screen, .3 is three tenths down from the first line, and so on.  If the line is specified as a frac‐[23;15Htion, the actual line number is recalculated if the terminal window is resized, so that the target line remains at the spec‐[24;15Hified fraction of the screen height.  If any form of the -j option is used, repeated forward searches (invoked with  "n"  or[25;15H"N")  begin  at  the line immediately after the target line, and repeated backward searches begin at the target line, unless[26;15Hchanged by -a or -A.  For example, if "-j4" is used, the target line is the fourth line on the screen, so  forward  searches[27;15Hbegin at the fifth line on the screen.  However nonrepeated searches (invoked with "/" or "?")  always begin at the start or[28;15Hend of the current screen respectively.[K[29;1H[K[30;1H       -J or --status-column[31;8H       Displays a status column at the left edge of the screen.  The status column shows the lines that matched the current search.[32;15HThe status column is also used if the -w or -W option is in effect.[K[33;1H[K[34;1H       -kfilename or --lesskey-file=filename[35;8H       Causes  less  to  open  and  interpret  the named file as a lesskey (1) file.  Multiple -k options may be specified.  If the[36;15HLESSKEY or LESSKEY_SYSTEM environment variable is set, or if a lesskey file is found in a standard place (see KEY BINDINGS),[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       -hn or --max-back-scroll=n[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Specifies a maximum number of lines to scroll backward.  If it is necessary to scroll backward more than n lines, the screen[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15His repainted in a forward direction instead.  (If the terminal does  not  have  the  ability  to  scroll  backward,  -h0  is[36;1H[36;1H[2;1H              implied.)[3;1H[K[4;8H-i or --ignore-case[K[5;15HCauses  searches  to  ignore case; that is, uppercase and lowercase are considered identical.
