By default, less prompts with a colon.[25;9HM or --LONG-PROMPT[26;15HCauses less to prompt even more verbosely than more.[K[27;1H[K[28;1H       -n or --line-numbers[29;8H       Suppresses line numbers.  The default (to use line numbers) may cause less to run more slowly in some cases, especially with[30;15Ha  very  large  input file.  Suppressing line numbers with the -n option will avoid this problem.  Using line numbers means:[31;1H              the line number will be displayed in the verbose prompt and in the = command, and the v command will pass the  current  line[32;8H       number to the editor (see also the discussion of LESSEDIT in PROMPTS below).[33;1H[K[34;1H       -N or --LINE-NUMBERS[35;8H       Causes a line number to be displayed at the beginning of each line in the display.[36;1H[K[36;1H[1;15Hend of the current screen respectively.[K[2;1H[K[3;1H       -J or --status-column[4;8H       Displays a status column at the left edge of the screen.  The status column shows the lines that matched the current search.[5;15HThe status column is also used if the -w or -W option is in effect.[K[6;1H[K[7;1H       -kfilename or --lesskey-file=filename[8;8H       Causes  less  to  open  and  interpret  the named file as a lesskey (1) file.  Multiple -k options may be specified.  If the[9;15HLESSKEY or LESSKEY_SYSTEM environment variable is set, or if a lesskey file is found in a standard place (see KEY BINDINGS),[10;15Hit is also used as a lesskey file.[K[11;1H[K[12;1H       -K or --quit-on-intr[13;8H       Causes  less  to exit immediately (with status 2) when an interrupt character (usually ^C) is typed.  Normally, an interrupt[14;15Hcharacter causes less to stop whatever it is doing and return to its command prompt.  Note that use of this option makes  it[15;15Himpossible to return to the command prompt from the "F" command.[K[16;1H[K[17;1H       -L or --no-lessopen[18;8H       Ignore  the  LESSOPEN  environment  variable (see the INPUT PREPROCESSOR section below).  This option can be set from within[19;15Hless, but it will apply only to files opened subsequently, not to the file which is currently open.[K[20;1H[K[21;1H       -m or --long-prompt[22;8H       Causes less to prompt verbosely (like more), with the percent into the file.  By default, less prompts with a colon.[23;1H[K[24;1H       -M or --LONG-PROMPT[25;8H       Causes less to prompt even more verbosely than more.[26;1H[K[27;1H       -n or --line-numbers[28;8H       Suppresses line numbers.  The default (to use line numbers) may cause less to run more slowly in some cases, especially with[29;15Ha  very  large  input file.  Suppressing line numbers with the -n option will avoid this problem. If the file already exists, less will ask for confirmation before overwriting it.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       -Ofilename or --LOG-FILE=filename[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       The -O option is like -o, but it will overwrite an existing file without asking for confirmation.[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[2;1H              If no log file has been specified, the -o and -O options can be used from within less to specify a log file.  Without a file[3;8H       name, they will simply report the name of the log file.  The "s" command is equivalent to specifying -o from within less.[4;1H[K[5;8H-ppattern or --pattern=pattern[K[6;1H              The -p option on the command line is equivalent to specifying +/pattern; that is, it tells less to start at the first occur‐[7;8H       rence of pattern in the file.[8;1H[K[9;1H       -Pprompt or --prompt=prompt[10;15HProvides a way to tailor the three prompt styles to your own preference.  This option would normally  be  put  in  the  LESS[11;15Henvironment  variable,  rather than being typed in with each less command.  Such an option must either be the last option in[12;1H              the LESS variable, or be terminated by a dollar sign.[13;8H        -Ps followed by a string changes the default (short) prompt to that string.[14;15H -Pm changes the medium (-m) prompt.[K[15;15H -PM changes the long (-M) prompt.[16;1H               -Ph changes the prompt for the help screen.[17;8H        -P= changes the message printed by the = command.[18;15H -Pw changes the message printed while waiting for data (in the F command).  All prompt strings consist  of  a  sequence  of[19;15Hletters and special escape sequences.  See the section on PROMPTS for more details.[K[20;1H[K[21;8H-q or --quiet or --silent[K[22;15HCauses  moderately "quiet" operation: the terminal bell is not rung if an attempt is made to scroll past the end of the file[23;15Hor before the beginning of the file.  If the terminal has a "visual bell", it is used instead.  The bell  will  be  rung  on[24;15Hcertain other errors, such as typing an invalid character.  The default is to ring the terminal bell in all such cases.[25;1H[K[26;8H-Q or --QUIET or --SILENT[K[27;15HCauses totally "quiet" operation: the terminal bell is never rung.[K[29;9Hr or --raw-control-chars[30;22H"raw" control characters to be displayed.  The default is to display control characters using the caret notation; for[31;15Hexample, a control-A (octal 001) is displayed as "^A".  Warning: when the -r option is used, less cannot keep track  of  the[32;15Hactual  appearance  of  the screen (since this depends on how the screen responds to each type of control character).  Thus,[33;1H              various display problems may result, such as long lines being split in the wrong place.[34;1H[K[35;8H-R or --RAW-CONTROL-CHARS[K[36;1H              Like -r, but only ANSI "color" escape sequences are output in "raw" form.  Unlike -r, the screen  appearance  is  maintained[36;1H[1;1H              If no log file has been specified, the -o and -O options can be used from within less to specify a log file. The "s" command is equivalent to specifying -o from within less.[K[3;1H[K[4;1H       -ppattern or --pattern=pattern[5;8H       The -p option on the command line is equivalent to specifying +/pattern; that is, it tells less to start at the first occur‐[6;15Hrence of pattern in the file.[K[7;1H[K[8;1H       -Pprompt or --prompt=prompt[9;8H       Provides a way to tailor the three prompt styles to your own preference.  This option would normally  be  put  in  the  LESS[10;15Henvironment  variable,  rather than being typed in with each less command.  Such an option must either be the last option in[11;15Hthe LESS variable, or be terminated by a dollar sign.[K[12;15H -Ps followed by a string changes the default (short) prompt to that string.[13;18Hm changes the medium (-m) prompt.[K[14;18HM changes the long (-M) prompt.[K[15;18Hh changes the prompt for the help screen.[16;18H= changes the message printed by the = command.[17;18Hw changes the message printed while waiting for data (in the F command). The default is to display control characters using the caret notation; for[30;15Hexample, a control-A (octal 001) is displayed as "^A".  Warning: when the -r option is used, less cannot keep track  of  the[31;15Hactual  appearance  of  the screen (since this depends on how the screen responds to each type of control character).  Thus,[32;15Hvarious display problems may result, such as long lines being split in the wrong place.[K[33;1H[K[34;1H       -R or --RAW-CONTROL-CHARS[35;8H       Like -r, but only ANSI "color" escape sequences are output in "raw" form.  Unlike -r, the screen  appearance  is  maintained[36;15Hcorrectly in most cases.  ANSI "color" escape sequences are sequences of the form:[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hname, they will simply report the name of the log file. ANSI "color" escape sequences are sequences of the form:[29;1H[K[30;15H     ESC [ ... m[K[31;1H[K[32;15Hwhere  the  "..." is zero or more color specification characters For the purpose of keeping track of screen appearance, ANSI[33;1H              color escape sequences are assumed to not move the cursor. And you can make less think that characters other than the standard ones may appear between the  ESC[36;15Hand the m by setting the environment variable LESSANSIMIDCHARS to the list of characters which can appear.[36;1H[1;15Henvironment  variable,  rather than being typed in with each less command. For this to work, tag information[32;8H       must be available; for example, there may be a file in the current directory called "tags", which was  previously  built  by[33;15Hctags (1) or an equivalent command.  If the environment variable LESSGLOBALTAGS is set, it is taken to be the name of a com‐[34;15Hmand  compatible  with  global  (1),  and  that  command  is  executed  to  find  the  tag. The command ":t" is equivalent to specifying -t from within less.[36;1H[1;8H       Causes totally "quiet" operation: the terminal bell is never rung.[2;1H[K[3;1H       -r or --raw-control-chars[4;8H       Causes "raw" control characters to be displayed. The default is to display control characters using the caret notation; for[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[37;1H[7m-----Info: (*manpages*)less, 1181 lines --44%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[0m[1;15Hexample, a control-A (octal 001) is displayed as "^A".  Warning: when the -r option is used, less cannot keep track  of  the[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hactual  appearance  of  the screen (since this depends on how the screen responds to each type of control character).  Thus,[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hvarious display problems may result, such as long lines being split in the wrong place.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[2;1H       -R or --RAW-CONTROL-CHARS[3;8H       Like -r, but only ANSI "color" escape sequences are output in "raw" form.  Unlike -r, the screen  appearance  is  maintained[4;15Hcorrectly in most cases.  ANSI "color" escape sequences are sequences of the form:[K[5;1H[K[6;15H     ESC [ ... m[K[7;1H[K[8;1H              where  the  "..." is zero or more color specification characters For the purpose of keeping track of screen appearance, ANSI[9;8H       color escape sequences are assumed to not move the cursor.  You can make less think that characters other than "m"  can  end[10;15HANSI  color  escape sequences by setting the environment variable LESSANSIENDCHARS to the list of characters which can end a[11;17Hlor escape sequence.  And you can make less think that characters other than the standard ones may appear between the  ESC[12;1H              and the m by setting the environment variable LESSANSIMIDCHARS to the list of characters which can appear.[13;1H[K[14;1H       -s or --squeeze-blank-lines[15;15HCauses consecutive blank lines to be squeezed into a single blank line.  This is useful when viewing nroff output.[K[16;1H[K[17;8H-S or --chop-long-lines[K[18;15HCauses  lines  longer  than  the screen width to be chopped (truncated) rather than wrapped.  That is, the portion of a long[19;15Hline that does not fit in the screen width is not shown.  The default is to wrap long lines; that is, display the  remainder[20;1H              on the next line.[21;1H[K[22;8H-ttag or --tag=tag[K[23;1H              The  -t  option,  followed  immediately by a TAG, will edit the file containing that tag.  For this to work, tag information[24;8H       must be available; for example, there may be a file in the current directory called "tags", which was  previously  built  by[25;15Hctags (1) or an equivalent command.  If the environment variable LESSGLOBALTAGS is set, it is taken to be the name of a com‐[26;15Hmand  compatible  with  global  (1),  and  that  command  is  executed  to  find  the  tag.   (See  http://www.gnu.org/soft‐[27;15Hware/global/global.html).   The -t option may also be specified from within less (using the - command) as a way of examining[28;1H              a new file.  The command ":t" is equivalent to specifying -t from within less.[29;1H[K[30;8H-Ttagsfile or --tag-file=tagsfile[K[31;15HSpecifies a tags file to be used instead of "tags".[K[32;1H[K[33;8H-u or --underline-special[K[34;15HCauses backspaces and carriage returns to be treated as printable characters; that is, they are sent to  the  terminal  when[35;15Hthey appear in the input.[K[36;1H[1;1H       -R or --RAW-CONTROL-CHARS[2;8H       Like -r, but only ANSI "color" escape sequences are output in "raw" form.  Unlike -r, the screen  appearance  is  maintained[3;15Hcorrectly in most cases.  ANSI "color" escape sequences are sequences of the form:[K[4;1H[K[5;1H                   ESC [ ... m[6;1H[K[7;1H              where  the  "..." is zero or more color specification characters For the purpose of keeping track of screen appearance, ANSI[8;15Hcolor escape sequences are assumed to not move the cursor.  You can make less think that characters other than "m"  can  end[9;15HANSI  color  escape sequences by setting the environment variable LESSANSIENDCHARS to the list of characters which can end a[10;15Hcolor escape sequence.  And you can make less think that characters other than the standard ones may appear between the  ESC[11;15Hand the m by setting the environment variable LESSANSIMIDCHARS to the list of characters which can appear.[K[12;1H[K[13;1H       -s or --squeeze-blank-lines[14;8H       Causes consecutive blank lines to be squeezed into a single blank line.  This is useful when viewing nroff output.[15;1H[K[16;1H       -S or --chop-long-lines[17;8H       Causes  lines  longer  than  the screen width to be chopped (truncated) rather than wrapped.  That is, the portion of a long[18;15Hline that does not fit in the screen width is not shown.  The default is to wrap long lines; that is, display the  remainder[19;15Hon the next line.[K[20;1H[K[21;1H       -ttag or --tag=tag[22;8H       The  -t  option,  followed  immediately by a TAG, will edit the file containing that tag.  For this to work, tag information[23;15Hmust be available; for example, there may be a file in the current directory called "tags", which was  previously  built  by[24;15Hctags (1) or an equivalent command.  If the environment variable LESSGLOBALTAGS is set, it is taken to be the name of a com‐[25;15Hmand  compatible  with  global  (1),  and  that  command  is  executed  to  find  the  tag.   (See  http://www.gnu.org/soft‐[26;15Hware/global/global.html).   The -t option may also be specified from within less (using the - command) as a way of examining[27;15Ha new file.  The command ":t" is equivalent to specifying -t from within less.[K[28;1H[K[29;1H       -Ttagsfile or --tag-file=tagsfile[30;8H       Specifies a tags file to be used instead of "tags".[31;1H[K[32;1H       -u or --underline-special[33;8H       Causes backspaces and carriage returns to be treated as printable characters; that is, they are sent to  the  terminal  when[34;15Hthey appear in the input.[K[35;1H[K[36;1H       -U or --UNDERLINE-SPECIAL[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Like -r, but only ANSI "color" escape sequences are output in "raw" form.  Unlike -r, the screen  appearance  is  maintained[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hcorrectly in most cases.  ANSI "color" escape sequences are sequences of the form:[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H                   ESC [ ... m[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H              where  the  "..." is zero or more color specification characters For the purpose of keeping track of screen appearance, ANSI[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hcolor escape sequences are assumed to not move the cursor.  You can make less think that characters other than "m"  can  end[36;1H[36;1H[2;15HANSI  color  escape sequences by setting the environment variable LESSANSIENDCHARS to the list of characters which can end a[3;17Hlor escape sequence.  And you can make less think that characters other than the standard ones may appear between the  ESC[4;1H              and the m by setting the environment variable LESSANSIMIDCHARS to the list of characters which can appear.[5;1H[K[6;1H       -s or --squeeze-blank-lines[7;15HCauses consecutive blank lines to be squeezed into a single blank line.  This is useful when viewing nroff output.[K[8;1H[K[9;8H-S or --chop-long-lines[K[10;15HCauses  lines  longer  than  the screen width to be chopped (truncated) rather than wrapped. The default is to wrap long lines; that is, display the  remainder[12;1H              on the next line.[13;1H[K[14;8H-ttag or --tag=tag[K[15;1H              The  -t  option,  followed  immediately by a TAG, will edit the file containing that tag.  For this to work, tag information[16;8H       must be available; for example, there may be a file in the current directory called "tags", which was  previously  built  by[17;15Hctags (1) or an equivalent command.  If the environment variable LESSGLOBALTAGS is set, it is taken to be the name of a com‐[18;15Hmand  compatible  with  global  (1),  and  that  command  is  executed  to  find  the  tag.   (See  http://www.gnu.org/soft‐[19;15Hware/global/global.html).   The -t option may also be specified from within less (using the - command) as a way of examining[20;1H              a new file.  The command ":t" is equivalent to specifying -t from within less.[21;1H[K[22;8H-Ttagsfile or --tag-file=tagsfile[K[23;15HSpecifies a tags file to be used instead of "tags".[K[24;1H[K[25;8H-u or --underline-special[K[26;15HCauses backspaces and carriage returns to be treated as printable characters; that is, they are sent to  the  terminal  when[27;15Hthey appear in the input.[K[29;9HU or --UNDERLINE-SPECIAL[K[30;15HCauses  backspaces, tabs and carriage returns to be treated as control characters; that is, they are handled as specified by[31;1H              the -r option.[32;1H[K[33;15HBy default, if neither -u nor -U is given, backspaces which appear adjacent to an  underscore  character  are  treated  spe‐[34;15Hcially:  the  underlined  text  is  displayed  using the terminal's hardware underlining capability.  Also, backspaces which[35;1H              appear between two identical characters are treated specially: the overstruck text is printed using the terminal's  hardware[36;8H       boldface  capability.   Other backspaces are deleted, along with the preceding character.  Carriage returns immediately fol‐[36;1H[37;1H[7m-----Info: (*manpages*)less, 1181 lines --45%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[0m[1;15HANSI  color  escape sequences by setting the environment variable LESSANSIENDCHARS to the list of characters which can end a[2;15Hcolor escape sequence.  And you can make less think that characters other than the standard ones may appear between the  ESC[3;15Hand the m by setting the environment variable LESSANSIMIDCHARS to the list of characters which can appear.[K[4;1H[K[5;1H       -s or --squeeze-blank-lines[6;8H       Causes consecutive blank lines to be squeezed into a single blank line.  This is useful when viewing nroff output.[7;1H[K[8;1H       -S or --chop-long-lines[9;8H       Causes  lines  longer  than  the screen width to be chopped (truncated) rather than wrapped.  That is, the portion of a long[10;15Hline that does not fit in the screen width is not shown.  The default is to wrap long lines; that is, display the  remainder[11;15Hon the next line.[K[12;1H[K[13;1H       -ttag or --tag=tag[14;8H       The  -t  option,  followed  immediately by a TAG, will edit the file containing that tag. If the environment variable LESSGLOBALTAGS is set, it is taken to be the name of a com‐[17;15Hmand  compatible  with  global  (1),  and  that  command  is  executed  to  find  the  tag. The command ":t" is equivalent to specifying -t from within less.[K[20;1H[K[21;1H       -Ttagsfile or --tag-file=tagsfile[22;8H       Specifies a tags file to be used instead of "tags".[23;1H[K[24;1H       -u or --underline-special[25;8H       Causes backspaces and carriage returns to be treated as printable characters; that is, they are sent to  the  terminal  when[26;15Hthey appear in the input.[K[27;1H[K[28;1H       -U or --UNDERLINE-SPECIAL[29;8H       Causes  backspaces, tabs and carriage returns to be treated as control characters; that is, they are handled as specified by[30;15Hthe -r option.[K[31;1H[K[32;1H              By default, if neither -u nor -U is given, backspaces which appear adjacent to an  underscore  character  are  treated  spe‐[33;15Hcially:  the  underlined  text  is  displayed  using the terminal's hardware underlining capability.  Also, backspaces which[34;15Happear between two identical characters are treated specially: the overstruck text is printed using the terminal's  hardware[35;15Hboldface  capability.   Other backspaces are deleted, along with the preceding character.  Carriage returns immediately fol‐[36;15Hlowed by a newline are deleted.  Other carriage returns are handled as specified by the -r option.  Text which is overstruck[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hcolor escape sequence.  And you can make less think that characters other than the standard ones may appear between the  ESC[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hand the m by setting the environment variable LESSANSIMIDCHARS to the list of characters which can appear.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       -s or --squeeze-blank-lines[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Causes consecutive blank lines to be squeezed into a single blank line.  This is useful when viewing nroff output.[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       -S or --chop-long-lines[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Causes  lines  longer  than  the screen width to be chopped (truncated) rather than wrapped.  That is, the portion of a long[36;1H[36;1H[2;15Hline that does not fit in the screen width is not shown.  The default is to wrap long lines; that is, display the  remainder[3;15Hon the next line.[K[5;9Httag or --tag=tag[K[6;15HThe  -t  option,  followed  immediately by a TAG, will edit the file containing that tag.  For this to work, tag information[7;1H              must be available; for example, there may be a file in the current directory called "tags", which was  previously  built  by[8;8H       ctags (1) or an equivalent command.  If the environment variable LESSGLOBALTAGS is set, it is taken to be the name of a com‐[9;15Hmand  compatible  with  global  (1),  and  that  command  is  executed  to  find  the  tag. Also, backspaces which[26;15Happear between two identical characters are treated specially: the overstruck text is printed using the terminal's  hardware[27;1H              boldface  capability.   Other backspaces are deleted, along with the preceding character.  Carriage returns immediately fol‐[28;8H       lowed by a newline are deleted.  Other carriage returns are handled as specified by the -r option.  Text which is overstruck[29;15Hor underlined can be searched for if neither -u nor -U is in effect.[K[30;1H[K[31;1H       -V or --version[32;15HDisplays the version number of less.[K[33;1H[K[34;8H-w or --hilite-unread[K[35;15HTemporarily highlights the first "new" line after a forward movement of a full page.  The first "new" line is the line imme‐[36;15Hdiately following the line previously at the bottom of the screen.  Also highlights the target line after a g or p  command.[36;1H[1;15Hline that does not fit in the screen width is not shown.  The default is to wrap long lines; that is, display the  remainder[2;15Hon the next line.[K[3;1H[K[4;1H       -ttag or --tag=tag[5;8H       The  -t  option,  followed  immediately by a TAG, will edit the file containing that tag. Also, backspaces which[16;15Happear between two identical characters are treated specially: the overstruck text is printed using the terminal's  hardware[17;15Hboldface  capability. If only one n is specified, tab stops are set at multiples of n.  If multiple values  separated  by  commas[35;15Hare  specified, tab stops are set at those positions, and then continue with the same spacing as the last two.  For example,[36;15H-x9,17 will set tabs at positions 9, 17, 25, 33, etc.  The default for n is 8.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       -Ttagsfile or --tag-file=tagsfile[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Specifies a tags file to be used instead of "tags".[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[37;1H[7m-----Info: (*manpages*)less, 1181 lines --47%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[0m[1;1H       -u or --underline-special[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;8H       Causes backspaces and carriage returns to be treated as printable characters; that is, they are sent to  the  terminal  when[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hthey appear in the input.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H       -U or --UNDERLINE-SPECIAL[36;1H[36;1H[2;1H              Causes  backspaces, tabs and carriage returns to be treated as control characters; that is, they are handled as specified by[3;8H       the -r option.[K[4;1H[K[5;1H              By default, if neither -u nor -U is given, backspaces which appear adjacent to an  underscore  character  are  treated  spe‐[6;8H       cially:  the  underlined  text  is  displayed  using the terminal's hardware underlining capability.  Also, backspaces which[7;15Happear between two identical characters are treated specially: the overstruck text is printed using the terminal's  hardware[8;15Hboldface  capability.   Other backspaces are deleted, along with the preceding character.  Carriage returns immediately fol‐[9;1H              lowed by a newline are deleted.  Other carriage returns are handled as specified by the -r option.  Text which is overstruck[10;8H       or underlined can be searched for if neither -u nor -U is in effect.[11;1H[K[12;8H-V or --version[K[13;1H              Displays the version number of less.[14;1H[K[15;8H-w or --hilite-unread[K[16;15HTemporarily highlights the first "new" line after a forward movement of a full page.  The first "new" line is the line imme‐[17;15Hdiately following the line previously at the bottom of the screen.  Also highlights the target line after a g or p  command.[18;15HThe highlight is removed at the next command which causes movement.  The entire line is highlighted, unless the -J option is[19;15Hin effect, in which case only the status column is highlighted.[K[21;9HW or --HILITE-UNREAD[22;15HLike -w, but temporarily highlights the first new line after any forward movement command larger than one line.[24;9Hxn,... or --tabs=n,...[25;15HSets tab stops.  If only one n is specified, tab stops are set at multiples of n.  If multiple values  separated  by  commas[26;15Hare  specified, tab stops are set at those positions, and then continue with the same spacing as the last two.  For example,[27;15H-x9,17 will set tabs at positions 9, 17, 25, 33, etc.  The default for n is 8.[K[28;1H[K[29;1H       -X or --no-init[30;8H       Disables sending the termcap initialization and deinitialization strings to the terminal.  This is  sometimes  desirable  if[31;15Hthe deinitialization string does something unnecessary, like clearing the screen.[K[33;9Hyn or --max-forw-scroll=n[34;16Hpecifies  a  maximum number of lines to scroll forward.  If it is necessary to scroll forward more than n lines, the screen[35;15His repainted instead.  The -c or -C option may be used to repaint from the top of the screen if desired.   By  default,  any[36;15Hforward movement causes scrolling.[K[36;1H[1;8H       Causes  backspaces, tabs and carriage returns to be treated as control characters; that is, they are handled as specified by[2;15Hthe -r option.[K[3;1H[K[4;1H              By default, if neither -u nor -U is given, backspaces which appear adjacent to an  underscore  character  are  treated  spe‐[5;15Hcially:  the  underlined  text  is  displayed  using the terminal's hardware underlining capability.  Also, backspaces which[6;15Happear between two identical characters are treated specially: the overstruck text is printed using the terminal's  hardware[7;15Hboldface  capability.   Other backspaces are deleted, along with the preceding character.  Carriage returns immediately fol‐[8;15Hlowed by a newline are deleted.  Other carriage returns are handled as specified by the -r option. The first "new" line is the line imme‐[16;15Hdiately following the line previously at the bottom of the screen.  Also highlights the target line after a g or p  command.[17;15HThe highlight is removed at the next command which causes movement.  The entire line is highlighted, unless the -J option is[18;15Hin effect, in which case only the status column is highlighted.[K[19;1H[K[20;1H       -W or --HILITE-UNREAD[21;8H       Like -w, but temporarily highlights the first new line after any forward movement command larger than one line.[22;1H[K[23;1H       -xn,... or --tabs=n,...[24;8H       Sets tab stops.  If only one n is specified, tab stops are set at multiples of n.  If multiple values  separated  by  commas[25;15Hare  specified, tab stops are set at those positions, and then continue with the same spacing as the last two. If it is necessary to scroll forward more than n lines, the screen[34;15His repainted instead.  The -c or -C option may be used to repaint from the top of the screen if desired.   By  default,  any[35;15Hforward movement causes scrolling.[K[36;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hthe -r option.[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H[K[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;1H              By default, if neither -u nor -U is given, backspaces which appear adjacent to an  underscore  character  are  treated  spe‐[36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[1;15Hcially:  the  underlined  text  is  displayed  using the terminal's hardware underlining capability. The z and w commands can also be used[30;16Ho change the window size.  The "z" may be omitted for compatibility with some versions of more.  If the number n  is  nega‐[31;1H              tive,  it  indicates  n  lines  less  than  the  current screen size.  For example, if the screen is 24 lines, -z-4 sets the[32;8H       scrolling window to 20 lines. This option causes lines after end of file to be dis‐[25;15Hplayed as blank lines.[K[26;1H[K[27;8H-# or --shift[K[28;15HSpecifies the default number of positions to scroll horizontally in the RIGHTARROW and LEFTARROW commands.   If  the  number[29;16Hpecified  is zero, it sets the default number of positions to one half of the screen width.  Alternately, the number may be[30;15Hspecified as a fraction of the width of the screen, starting with a decimal point: .5 is half of the  screen  width,  .3  is[31;1H              three  tenths  of  the screen width, and so on.  If the number is specified as a fraction, the actual number of scroll posi‐[32;8H       tions is recalculated if the terminal window is resized, so that the actual scroll remains at the specified fraction of  the[33;15Hscreen width.[K[34;1H[K[35;1H       --follow-name[36;8H       Normally,  if  the  input file is renamed while an F command is executing, less will continue to display the contents of the[36;1H[37;1H[7m-----Info: (*manpages*)less, 1181 lines --50%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------[0m[1;15Hthe deinitialization string does something unnecessary, like clearing the screen.[K[2;1H[K[3;1H       -yn or --max-forw-scroll=n[4;8H       Specifies  a  maximum number of lines to scroll forward. Followed  by  two  characters,[10;15Hchanges  the  open  quote to the first character, and the close quote to the second character.  Filenames containing a space[11;15Hshould then be preceded by the open quote character and followed by the close quote character.  Note  that  even  after  the[12;15Hquote characters are changed, this option remains -" (a dash followed by a double quote).[K[14;9H~ or --tilde[K[15;15HNormally lines after end of file are displayed as a single tilde (~).  This option causes lines after end of file to be dis‐[16;15Hplayed as blank lines.[K[17;1H[K[18;8H-# or --shift[K[19;15HSpecifies the default number of positions to scroll horizontally in the RIGHTARROW and LEFTARROW commands.   If  the  number[20;15Hspecified  is zero, it sets the default number of positions to one half of the screen width.  Alternately, the number may be[21;1H              specified as a fraction of the width of the screen, starting with a decimal point: .5 is half of the  screen  width,  .3  is[22;8H       three  tenths  of  the screen width, and so on.  If the number is specified as a fraction, the actual number of scroll posi‐[23;15Htions is recalculated if the terminal window is resized, so that the actual scroll remains at the specified fraction of  the[24;15Hscreen width.[K[26;9H-follow-name[27;15HNormally,  if  the  input file is renamed while an F command is executing, less will continue to display the contents of the[28;15Horiginal file despite its name change.  If --follow-name is specified, during an F command less will periodically attempt to[29;15Hreopen  the file by name.  If the reopen succeeds and the file is a different file from the original (which means that a new[30;15Hfile has been created with the same name as the original (now renamed) file), less will display the  contents  of  that  new[31;15Hfile.[K[32;1H[K[33;1H       --no-keypad[34;8H       Disables  sending  the  keypad initialization and deinitialization strings to the terminal.  This is sometimes useful if the[35;15Hkeypad strings make the numeric keypad behave in an undesirable manner.[K[36;1H[K[36;1H[1;15Hto change the window size.  The "z" may be omitted for compatibility with some versions of more.  If the number n  is  nega‐[2;16Hive,  it  indicates  n  lines  less  than  the  current screen size.  For example, if the screen is 24 lines, -z-4 sets the[3;15Hscrolling window to 20 lines.  If the screen is resized to 40 lines, the scrolling window automatically changes to 36 lines.[4;1H[K[5;1H       -"cc or --quotes=cc[6;8H       Changes the filename quoting character.  This may be necessary if you are trying to name a file which contains  both  spaces[7;15Hand  quote  characters.  Followed by a single character, this changes the quote character to that character.  Filenames con‐[8;15Htaining a space should then be surrounded by that character rather than by  double  quotes.   Followed  by  two  characters,[9;15Hchanges  the  open  quote to the first character, and the close quote to the second character.  Filenames containing a space[10;15Hshould then be preceded by the open quote character and followed by the close quote character.  Note  that  even  after  the[11;15Hquote characters are changed, this option remains -" (a dash followed by a double quote).[K[12;1H[K[13;1H       -~ or --tilde[14;8H       Normally lines after end of file are displayed as a single tilde (~).  This option causes lines after end of file to be dis‐[15;15Hplayed as blank lines.[K[16;1H[K[17;1H       -# or --shift[18;8H       Specifies the default number of positions to scroll horizontally in the RIGHTARROW and LEFTARROW commands.   If  the  number[19;15Hspecified  is zero, it sets the default number of positions to one half of the screen width.  Alternately, the number may be[20;25Has a fraction of the width of the screen, starting with a decimal point: .5 is half of the  screen  width,  .3  is[21;15Hthree  tenths  of  the screen width, and so on.  If the number is specified as a fraction, the actual number of scroll posi‐[22;16Hions is recalculated if the terminal window is resized, so that the actual scroll remains at the specified fraction of  the[23;15Hscreen width.[K[24;1H[K[25;1H       --follow-name[26;8H       Normally,  if  the  input file is renamed while an F command is executing, less will continue to display the contents of the[27;15Horiginal file despite its name change. If the reopen succeeds and the file is a different file from the original (which means that a new[29;15Hfile has been created with the same name as the original (now renamed) file), less will display the  contents  of  that  new[30;19H.[K[31;1H[K[32;1H       --no-keypad[33;8H       Disables  sending  the  keypad initialization and deinitialization strings to the terminal. After the --use-backslash option,  any  backslash[30;15Hin  an option string is removed and the following character is taken literally.  This allows a dollar sign to be included in[31;1H              option strings.[32;1H[K[33;8H--     A command line argument of "--" marks the end of option arguments. Any arguments following this are  interpreted  as  file‐[27;8H       names.  This can be useful when viewing a file whose name begins with a "-" or "+".[28;1H[K[29;8H+      If  a  command line option begins with +, the remainder of that option is taken to be an initial command to less.  For exam‐[30;15Hple, +G tells less to start at the end of the file rather than the beginning, and +/xyz tells  it  to  start  at  the  first[31;1H              occurrence  of  "xyz" in the file.  As a special case, +<number> acts like +<number>g; that is, it starts the display at the[32;8H       specified line number (however, see the caveat under the "g" command above).  If the option starts with ++, the initial com‐[33;15Hmand applies to every file being viewed, not just the first one.  The + command described previously may also be used to set[34;1H              (or change) an initial command for every file.[35;1H[K[36;1HLINE EDITING[K[36;1H[1;1H       -# or --shift[2;8H       Specifies the default number of positions to scroll horizontally in the RIGHTARROW and LEFTARROW commands. Most commands have an alternate form in [ brackets ] which can[32;8Hbe used if a key does not exist on a particular keyboard.  (Note that the forms beginning with ESC do not work in some  MS-DOS  and[33;8HWindows  systems because ESC is the line erase character.)  Any of these special keys may be entered literally by preceding it with[34;1H       the "literal" character, either ^V or ^A. (Note that the forms beginning with ESC do not work in some  MS-DOS  and[28;1H       Windows  systems because ESC is the line erase character.)  Any of these special keys may be entered literally by preceding it with[29;8Hthe "literal" character, either ^V or ^A.  A backslash itself may also be entered literally by entering two backslashes.[K[30;1H[K[31;8HLEFTARROW [ ESC-h ][K[32;8H       Move the cursor one space to the left.[K[33;1H[K[34;1H       RIGHTARROW [ ESC-l ][35;8H       Move the cursor one space to the right.[36;1H[K[36;1H[1;15Hfile has been created with the same name as the original (now renamed) file), less will display the  contents  of  that  new[2;19H.[K[3;1H[K[4;1H       --no-keypad[5;8H       Disables  sending  the  keypad initialization and deinitialization strings to the terminal.  This is sometimes useful if the[6;15Hkeypad strings make the numeric keypad behave in an undesirable manner.[K[7;1H[K[8;1H       --use-backslash[9;8H       This option changes the interpretations of options which follow this one.  After the --use-backslash option,  any  backslash[10;15Hin  an option string is removed and the following character is taken literally.  This allows a dollar sign to be included in[11;15Hoption strings.[K[12;1H[K[13;1H       --     A command line argument of "--" marks the end of option arguments.  Any arguments following this are  interpreted  as  file‐[14;8H       names.  This can be useful when viewing a file whose name begins with a "-" or "+".[K[15;1H[K[16;1H       +      If  a  command line option begins with +, the remainder of that option is taken to be an initial command to less.  For exam‐[17;8H       ple, +G tells less to start at the end of the file rather than the beginning, and +/xyz tells  it  to  start  at  the  first[18;15Hoccurrence  of  "xyz" in the file.  As a special case, +<number> acts like +<number>g; that is, it starts the display at the[19;15Hspecified line number (however, see the caveat under the "g" command above).  If the option starts with ++, the initial com‐[20;15Hmand applies to every file being viewed, not just the first one.  The + command described previously may also be used to set[21;15H(or change) an initial command for every file.[K[22;1H[K[23;1HLINE EDITING[24;1H       When entering command line at the bottom of the screen (for example, a filename for the :e command, or the  pattern  for  a  search[25;8Hcommand),  certain keys can be used to manipulate the command line.  Most commands have an alternate form in [ brackets ] which can[26;8Hbe used if a key does not exist on a particular keyboard.  (Note that the forms beginning with ESC do not work in some  MS-DOS  and[27;8HWindows  systems because ESC is the line erase character.)  Any of these special keys may be entered literally by preceding it with[28;8Hthe "literal" character, either ^V or ^A.  A backslash itself may also be entered literally by entering two backslashes.[K[29;1H[K[30;1H       LEFTARROW [ ESC-h ][31;8H       Move the cursor one space to the left.[32;1H[K[33;1H       RIGHTARROW [ ESC-l ][34;8H       Move the cursor one space to the right.[35;1H[K[36;1H       ^LEFTARROW [ ESC-b or ESC-LEFTARROW ][36;1H[36;1H[36;1H[38;1H[K[?1l>[?1049l[23;0;0t[38;1H[K[?1l>[?1049l[23;0;0t]0;seguridad@admin1-Latitude-3490: ~/Escritorio/pki-example-1/etc[01;32mseguridad@admin1-Latitude-3490[00m:[01;34m~/Escritorio/pki-example-1/etc[00m$ info lesshelp less*less root-ca.conf 
[?1049h[22;0;0t[?1h=# Simple Root CA

# The [default] section contains global constants that can be referred to from
# the entire configuration file. It may also hold settings pertaining to more
# than one openssl command.

[ default ]
ca                      = root-ca               # CA name
dir                     = .                     # Top dir

# The next part of the configuration file is used by the openssl req command.
# It defines the CA's key pair, its DN, and the desired extensions for the CA
# certificate.

[ req ]
default_bits            = 2048                  # RSA key size
encrypt_key             = yes                   # Protect private key
default_md              = sha1                  # MD to use
utf8                    = yes                   # Input is UTF-8
string_mask             = utf8only              # Emit UTF-8 strings
prompt                  = no                    # Don't prompt for DN
distinguished_name      = ca_dn                 # DN section
req_extensions          = ca_reqext             # Desired extensions

[ ca_dn ]
0.domainComponent       = "org"
1.domainComponent       = "simple"
organizationName        = "Simple Inc"
organizationalUnitName  = "Simple Root CA"
commonName              = "Simple Root CA"

[ ca_reqext ]
keyUsage                = critical,keyCertSign,cRLSign
basicConstraints        = critical,CA:true
subjectKeyIdentifier    = hash

# The remainder of the configuration file is used by the openssl ca command.
[7mroot-ca.conf[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# The CA section defines the locations of CA assets, as well as the policies
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# applying to the CA.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ ca ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_ca              = root_ca               # The default CA section
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ root_ca ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcertificate             = $dir/ca/$ca.crt       # The CA cert
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kprivate_key             = $dir/ca/$ca/private/$ca.key # CA private key
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Knew_certs_dir           = $dir/ca/$ca           # Certificate archive
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kserial                  = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.crt.srl # Serial number file
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcrlnumber               = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.crl.srl # CRL number file
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdatabase                = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.db # Index file
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kunique_subject          = no                    # Require unique subject
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_days            = 3652                  # How long to certify for
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_md              = sha1                  # MD to use
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kpolicy                  = match_pol             # Default naming policy
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kemail_in_dn             = no                    # Add email to cert DN
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kpreserve                = no                    # Keep passed DN ordering
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kname_opt                = ca_default            # Subject DN display options
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcert_opt                = ca_default            # Certificate display options
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcopy_extensions         = none                  # Copy extensions from CSR
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kx509_extensions         = signing_ca_ext        # Default cert extensions
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_crl_days        = 365                   # How long before next CRL
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcrl_extensions          = crl_ext               # CRL extensions
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# Naming policies control which parts of a DN end up in the certificate and
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# under what circumstances certification should be denied.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ match_pol ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KdomainComponent         = match                 # Must match 'simple.org'
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationName        = match                 # Must match 'Simple Inc'
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationalUnitName  = optional              # Included if present
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KcommonName              = supplied              # Must be present
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ any_pol ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KdomainComponent         = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KcountryName             = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KstateOrProvinceName     = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KlocalityName            = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationName        = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationalUnitName  = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KcommonName              = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KemailAddress            = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# Certificate extensions define what types of certificates the CA is able to
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# create.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ root_ca_ext ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KkeyUsage                = critical,keyCertSign,cRLSign
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KbasicConstraints        = critical,CA:true
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KsubjectKeyIdentifier    = hash
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KauthorityKeyIdentifier  = keyid:always

:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K

:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ root_ca ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcertificate             = $dir/ca/$ca.crt       # The CA cert
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kprivate_key             = $dir/ca/$ca/private/$ca.key # CA private key
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Knew_certs_dir           = $dir/ca/$ca           # Certificate archive
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kserial                  = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.crt.srl # Serial number file
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcrlnumber               = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.crl.srl # CRL number file
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdatabase                = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.db # Index file
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kunique_subject          = no                    # Require unique subject
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_days            = 3652                  # How long to certify for
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_md              = sha1                  # MD to use
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kpolicy                  = match_pol             # Default naming policy
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kemail_in_dn             = no                    # Add email to cert DN
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kpreserve                = no                    # Keep passed DN ordering
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kname_opt                = ca_default            # Subject DN display options
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcert_opt                = ca_default            # Certificate display options
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcopy_extensions         = none                  # Copy extensions from CSR
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kx509_extensions         = signing_ca_ext        # Default cert extensions
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_crl_days        = 365                   # How long before next CRL
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcrl_extensions          = crl_ext               # CRL extensions
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# Naming policies control which parts of a DN end up in the certificate and
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# under what circumstances certification should be denied.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ match_pol ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KdomainComponent         = match                 # Must match 'simple.org'
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationName        = match                 # Must match 'Simple Inc'
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationalUnitName  = optional              # Included if present
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KcommonName              = supplied              # Must be present
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ any_pol ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KdomainComponent         = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KcountryName             = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KstateOrProvinceName     = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KlocalityName            = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationName        = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationalUnitName  = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KcommonName              = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KemailAddress            = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# Certificate extensions define what types of certificates the CA is able to
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# create.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K

:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KbasicConstraints        = critical,CA:true
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KsubjectKeyIdentifier    = hash
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KauthorityKeyIdentifier  = keyid:always

:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KbasicConstraints        = critical,CA:true,pathlen:0
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMname_opt                = ca_default            # Subject DN display options
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMpreserve                = no                    # Keep passed DN ordering

[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# applying to the CA.
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# The CA section defines the locations of CA assets, as well as the policies
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# The remainder of the configuration file is used by the openssl ca command.
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMsubjectKeyIdentifier    = hash

[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMcommonName              = "Simple Root CA"
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMorganizationalUnitName  = "Simple Root CA"
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMorganizationName        = "Simple Inc"

[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM0.domainComponent       = "org"
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM[ ca_dn ]

[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMreq_extensions          = ca_reqext             # Desired extensions

[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMprompt                  = no                    # Don't prompt for DN
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMstring_mask             = utf8only              # Emit UTF-8 strings
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMutf8                    = yes                   # Input is UTF-8
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMdefault_md              = sha1                  # MD to use
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMencrypt_key             = yes                   # Protect private key
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMdefault_bits            = 2048                  # RSA key size
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM[ req ]
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# certificate.
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# It defines the CA's key pair, its DN, and the desired extensions for the CA
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# The next part of the configuration file is used by the openssl req command.

:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ root_ca_ext ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KkeyUsage                = critical,keyCertSign,cRLSign
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KbasicConstraints        = critical,CA:true
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KsubjectKeyIdentifier    = hash
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KauthorityKeyIdentifier  = keyid:always
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ signing_ca_ext ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KkeyUsage                = critical,keyCertSign,cRLSign

[?1049h[22;0;0t[?1h=# Simple Signing CA

# The [default] section contains global constants that can be referred to from
# the entire configuration file. It may also hold settings pertaining to more
# than one openssl command.

[ default ]
ca                      = signing-ca            # CA name
dir                     = .                     # Top dir

# The next part of the configuration file is used by the openssl req command.
# It defines the CA's key pair, its DN, and the desired extensions for the CA
# certificate.

[ req ]
default_bits            = 2048                  # RSA key size
encrypt_key             = yes                   # Protect private key
default_md              = sha1                  # MD to use
utf8                    = yes                   # Input is UTF-8
string_mask             = utf8only              # Emit UTF-8 strings
prompt                  = no                    # Don't prompt for DN
distinguished_name      = ca_dn                 # DN section
req_extensions          = ca_reqext             # Desired extensions

[ ca_dn ]
0.domainComponent       = "org"
1.domainComponent       = "simple"
organizationName        = "Simple Inc"
organizationalUnitName  = "Simple Signing CA"
commonName              = "Simple Signing CA"

[ ca_reqext ]
keyUsage                = critical,keyCertSign,cRLSign
basicConstraints        = critical,CA:true,pathlen:0
subjectKeyIdentifier    = hash

# The remainder of the configuration file is used by the openssl ca command.

:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# Simple Signing CA
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# The CA section defines the locations of CA assets, as well as the policies
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# applying to the CA.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ ca ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_ca              = signing_ca            # The default CA section
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ signing_ca ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcertificate             = $dir/ca/$ca.crt       # The CA cert
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kprivate_key             = $dir/ca/$ca/private/$ca.key # CA private key
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Knew_certs_dir           = $dir/ca/$ca           # Certificate archive
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kserial                  = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.crt.srl # Serial number file
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcrlnumber               = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.crl.srl # CRL number file
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdatabase                = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.db # Index file
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kunique_subject          = no                    # Require unique subject
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_days            = 730                   # How long to certify for
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_md              = sha1                  # MD to use
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kpolicy                  = match_pol             # Default naming policy
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kemail_in_dn             = no                    # Add email to cert DN
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kpreserve                = no                    # Keep passed DN ordering
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kname_opt                = ca_default            # Subject DN display options
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcert_opt                = ca_default            # Certificate display options
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcopy_extensions         = copy                  # Copy extensions from CSR
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kx509_extensions         = email_ext             # Default cert extensions
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kdefault_crl_days        = 7                     # How long before next CRL
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[Kcrl_extensions          = crl_ext               # CRL extensions
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# Naming policies control which parts of a DN end up in the certificate and
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# under what circumstances certification should be denied.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ match_pol ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KdomainComponent         = match                 # Must match 'simple.org'
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationName        = match                 # Must match 'Simple Inc'
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationalUnitName  = optional              # Included if present
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KcommonName              = supplied              # Must be present
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ any_pol ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KdomainComponent         = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KcountryName             = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KstateOrProvinceName     = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KlocalityName            = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationName        = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KorganizationalUnitName  = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KcommonName              = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KemailAddress            = optional
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# Certificate extensions define what types of certificates the CA is able to
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# create.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ email_ext ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KkeyUsage                = critical,digitalSignature,keyEncipherment
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KbasicConstraints        = CA:false
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KextendedKeyUsage        = emailProtection,clientAuth
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KsubjectKeyIdentifier    = hash
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KauthorityKeyIdentifier  = keyid:always
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[ server_ext ]
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[KkeyUsage                = critical,digitalSignature,keyEncipherment

[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# under what circumstances certification should be denied.
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM# Naming policies control which parts of a DN end up in the certificate and
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMcrl_extensions          = crl_ext               # CRL extensions
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMdefault_crl_days        = 7                     # How long before next CRL
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMx509_extensions         = email_ext             # Default cert extensions
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMcopy_extensions         = copy                  # Copy extensions from CSR
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMcert_opt                = ca_default            # Certificate display options
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMname_opt                = ca_default            # Subject DN display options
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMpreserve                = no                    # Keep passed DN ordering
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMemail_in_dn             = no                    # Add email to cert DN
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMpolicy                  = match_pol             # Default naming policy
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMdefault_md              = sha1                  # MD to use
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMdefault_days            = 730                   # How long to certify for
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMunique_subject          = no                    # Require unique subject
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMdatabase                = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.db # Index file
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMcrlnumber               = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.crl.srl # CRL number file
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMserial                  = $dir/ca/$ca/db/$ca.crt.srl # Serial number file
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMnew_certs_dir           = $dir/ca/$ca           # Certificate archive
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMprivate_key             = $dir/ca/$ca/private/$ca.key # CA private key
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HMcertificate             = $dir/ca/$ca.crt       # The CA cert
[38;1H[K:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM[ signing_ca ]

:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K

:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K# create.
:[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K

[?1049h[22;0;0t[?1h=# Email certificate request

# This file is used by the openssl req command. Since we cannot know the DN in
# advance the user is prompted for DN information.

[ req ]
default_bits            = 2048                  # RSA key size
encrypt_key             = yes                   # Protect private key
default_md              = sha1                  # MD to use
utf8                    = yes                   # Input is UTF-8
string_mask             = utf8only              # Emit UTF-8 strings
prompt                  = yes                   # Prompt for DN
distinguished_name      = email_dn              # DN template
req_extensions          = email_reqext          # Desired extensions

[ email_dn ]
0.domainComponent       = "1. Domain Component         (eg, com)      "
1.domainComponent       = "2. Domain Component         (eg, company)  "
2.domainComponent       = "3. Domain Component         (eg, pki)      "
organizationName        = "4. Organization Name        (eg, company)  "
organizationalUnitName  = "5. Organizational Unit Name (eg, section)  "
commonName              = "6. Common Name              (eg, full name)"
commonName_max          = 64
emailAddress            = "7. Email Address            (eg, name@fqdn)"
emailAddress_max        = 40

[ email_reqext ]
keyUsage                = critical,digitalSignature,keyEncipherment
extendedKeyUsage        = emailProtection,clientAuth
subjectKeyIdentifier    = hash
subjectAltName          = email:move
[7memail.conf (END)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[K[7m(END)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[K[7m(END)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[K[7m(END)[27m[K[K # Email certificate request

# This file is used by the openssl req command. Since we cannot know the DN in
# advance the user is prompted for DN information.

[ req ]
default_bits            = 2048                  # RSA key size
encrypt_key             = yes                   # Protect private key
default_md              = sha1                  # MD to use
utf8                    = yes                   # Input is UTF-8
string_mask             = utf8only              # Emit UTF-8 strings
prompt                  = yes                   # Prompt for DN
distinguished_name      = email_dn              # DN template
req_extensions          = email_reqext          # Desired extensions

[ email_dn ]
0.domainComponent       = "1. Domain Component         (eg, com)      "
1.domainComponent       = "2. Domain Component         (eg, company)  "
2.domainComponent       = "3. Domain Component         (eg, pki)      "
organizationName        = "4. Organization Name        (eg, company)  "
organizationalUnitName  = "5. Organizational Unit Name (eg, section)  "
commonName              = "6. Common Name              (eg, full name)"
commonName_max          = 64
emailAddress            = "7. Email Address            (eg, name@fqdn)"
emailAddress_max        = 40

[ email_reqext ]
keyUsage                = critical,digitalSignature,keyEncipherment
extendedKeyUsage        = emailProtection,clientAuth
subjectKeyIdentifier    = hash
subjectAltName          = email:move

[?1049h[22;0;0t[?1h=# TLS server certificate request

# This file is used by the openssl req command. The subjectAltName cannot be
# prompted for and must be specified in the SAN environment variable.

[ default ]
SAN                     = DNS:yourdomain.tld    # Default value

[ req ]
default_bits            = 2048                  # RSA key size
encrypt_key             = no                    # Protect private key
default_md              = sha1                  # MD to use
utf8                    = yes                   # Input is UTF-8
string_mask             = utf8only              # Emit UTF-8 strings
prompt                  = yes                   # Prompt for DN
distinguished_name      = server_dn             # DN template
req_extensions          = server_reqext         # Desired extensions

[ server_dn ]
0.domainComponent       = "1. Domain Component         (eg, com)      "
1.domainComponent       = "2. Domain Component         (eg, company)  "
2.domainComponent       = "3. Domain Component         (eg, pki)      "
organizationName        = "4. Organization Name        (eg, company)  "
organizationalUnitName  = "5. Organizational Unit Name (eg, section)  "
commonName              = "6. Common Name              (eg, FQDN)     "
commonName_max          = 64

[ server_reqext ]
keyUsage                = critical,digitalSignature,keyEncipherment
extendedKeyUsage        = serverAuth,clientAuth
subjectKeyIdentifier    = hash
subjectAltName          = $ENV::SAN
[7mserver.conf (END)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[K[7m(END)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[K[7m(END)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[K[7m(END)[27m[K[K # TLS server certificate request

# This file is used by the openssl req command. The subjectAltName cannot be
# prompted for and must be specified in the SAN environment variable.

[ default ]
SAN                     = DNS:yourdomain.tld    # Default value

[ req ]
default_bits            = 2048                  # RSA key size
encrypt_key             = no                    # Protect private key
default_md              = sha1                  # MD to use
utf8                    = yes                   # Input is UTF-8
string_mask             = utf8only              # Emit UTF-8 strings
prompt                  = yes                   # Prompt for DN
distinguished_name      = server_dn             # DN template
req_extensions          = server_reqext         # Desired extensions

[ server_dn ]
0.domainComponent       = "1. Domain Component         (eg, com)      "
1.domainComponent       = "2. Domain Component         (eg, company)  "
2.domainComponent       = "3. Domain Component         (eg, pki)      "
organizationName        = "4. Organization Name        (eg, company)  "
organizationalUnitName  = "5. Organizational Unit Name (eg, section)  "
commonName              = "6. Common Name              (eg, FQDN)     "
commonName_max          = 64

[ server_reqext ]
keyUsage                = critical,digitalSignature,keyEncipherment
extendedKeyUsage        = serverAuth,clientAuth
subjectKeyIdentifier    = hash
subjectAltName          = $ENV::SAN
[1m~[0m

writing new private key to 'certs/simple.org.key'
-----
You are about to be asked to enter information that will be incorporated
into your certificate request.
What you are about to enter is what is called a Distinguished Name or a DN.
There are quite a few fields but you can leave some blank
For some fields there will be a default value,
If you enter '.', the field will be left blank.
-----
1. Domain Component         (eg, com)       []:org
2. Domain Component         (eg, company)   []:simple
3. Domain Component         (eg, pki)       []:
4. Organization Name        (eg, company)   []:SImp   imple Inco 
5. Organizational Unit Name (eg, section)   []:
6. Common Name              (eg, FQDN)      []:www.simple.org
